  4228. I bought this razor several months ago and was pleasantly surprised at the quality, feel, and performance of it.
  4229. I have used an aftershave on the skin especially that seems sensitive on the neck and after a couple of weeks it has replaced my non-powered razor.

  4240. The 8 hr. wasn't worth the few dollars saved.

  4242. They are not very sharp and that's why they don't cut my skin.
  4243. I hope this lasts as long as my last one, but I remained brand loyal to Norelcos since the last one had a long service life.
  4244. It is so quiet that I can actually hear it cutting my whiskers -- a pleasant change from my 10 year old Braun.
  4245. Also, the new one has lithium batteries which last longer between shaves and are supposed to last longer before needing replacement.<br /><br
  4246. This is a sad commentary on the industry that the price of the replacement blades is more than I paid for the shaver new.
  4247. The Panasonic not only shaves extremely close, but is very fast.
  4248. Initially I did not want a battery unit but this one holds a charge for a very long time which makes it very convenient to use.
  4249. It shaves me in half the time, is a breeze to clean, just put under the water, let it dry, and move on.
  4250. After rinsing and gently shaking to remove dripping water, leave the head assembly open to air dry.
  4251. Takes 8 hours for full charging, that is too long as compared to any shaver that I have previously used.
  4252. This has a lithium ion battery which lasts longer as well as has a quick charge feature where you can charge it enough for one shave in a few minutes.
  4253. There's no mess, no fuss, no blades to replace, and no cuts (or necessary tissue).
  4254. Charges fast and a single charge last for about 2 weeks for me.
  4255. Razor requires future purchase of new heads in twelve months - never needed that before with Norelco - at least not that quickly.
  4256. Each time that I went back to shavers in the past, I had to endure a couple of weeks of significant skin irritation until my skin adjusted.
  4257. This razor has been very good at getting the little hairs and cutting all the way up to the skin.
  4258. But unlike older models, this has a deep, hard to reach compartment and it's more difficult to clean.
  4259. This shaver absolutely does not cut even small hair ,mainly in the neck region.
  4260. But the first time I used it I actually thought that there was some light plastic cover over the heads that I had failed to take off.
  4261. It doesn't offer any closer shave than any other electric I've used and it is not as close as a straight razor.
  4262. I'm not quite ready to go electric full-time - there's $60 of Gillette razor blades I'd have to use up first - but at least this razor leaves me thinking it's possible now.

All Reviews

  1. This is the workhorse of the electric razors. Bought it to replace my 10 yr old Norelco that finally died after I dropped it one too many times.<br />It s much lighter and quieter then the old model, so at first I felt like it is cheap/flimsy. It is anything but that. It is a light, well made razor, that is quiet and has a really long battery life. I think I've only charged it once in almost 2 months of use.<br />i also like the improvement in the head/blade removal - it is hinged, so I wont drop it into a trash can ever again trying to shake the stubble out.<br />I hope it lasts as long as my old one did!
  2. I bought it for my dad, he loves it.
  3. really does not cut the hair with out burns on my face

  5. My husband loves it !

  9. Very lightly made compared with the older Norelcos but that's probably a tribute to the Norelco engineering team to redesign and lower the manufacturing costs. I have nothing to rave about nor complain either. It shaves just fine...

  11. I'm very happy with this purchase, the shaver is quiet, smooth (does not pinch), and gives a very good shave. It is also very stylish, waterproof, cordless, and affordable.
  12. I am a long-term user of Norelco shavers and , having now used it fo a couple of weeks, the blades have adjusted to give me a shave better than any other electric shaver I have owned. Even a died-in-the wool razor addict would have little to complain about. Mind you there is the break-in phase to be aware of; give the Norelco a chance to break in and it will serve you well indeed.
  13. This is for my dad to buy , my father liked it very much . It shave very clean, and not much sound . My father uses it every day .<br />Now, he don't be worried about the rapid growth of beard

  15. Used ths Norelco to replace a Remington and much closer shave with Norelco. Quieter, easier to clean, better bang for the buck.
  16. Honestly I am disappointed with this electric razor after having used it for a month. It's not that it does not shave but the problem is that it is not a very powerful razor and for a person like me with not a lot of facial hair, I HAVE TO SPEND 15-20 MINUTES IN ORDER TO GET A CLOSE SHAVE. Also, I have to press the razor very hard on my face in order to shave the stubble AND IT LEAVES MY SKIN FEELING LIKE I SHAVED WITH SANDPAPER. Even my old shaver which was half the price of this new one used to do a better and faster job in half the time. I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND IT FOR THOSE FELLAS WITH A LOT OF FACIAL HAIR. The only positive features are that it stays charged long, the trimmer feature works well, it's light for carrying when traveling and it's easy to clean. I do not want to go through the trouble of returning it, but next time I will definitely invest my money on a better electric shaver even if it's a more expensive one. THAT'S MY ADVICE FOR ALL OF YOU GENTLEMEN THAT ARE CONSIDERING TO BUY THIS PARTICULAR PRODUCT.
  17. I have used it less than 5 times and use the cover that comes with it, so it doesn't get dinged up. Yet, I am already getting ready marks all over my neck without even pushing that hard. They last most of the day too, so I can't use it in the morning before work anymore.
  18. I gave this a five star because of the great shave it gives and because it is very quiet. I would recommend this product to anyone.
  19. I purchased this shaver October 2013. I've had no problems with it until two days ago. It suddenly wouldn't turn on. I had recharged it the day before so that can't be it. but I plugged in the charger cable anyway and I was able to turn it on. When I finished shaving it wouldn't turn off. Two minutes later I was able to turn it off. With the charger cable removed I tried turning it on and off again. That worked. I tried on again, nope, had to plug in the charger cable it wouldn't turn off. It's been some variation of the same confusing cycle for two days. At this price point it's a throw away item. I've ordered another model.

  26. I've used a Sensor Excel blade and nothing else for about twenty years. When I was a teen, I tried once or twice my father's ancient electric which was awful (even he barely ever had used it.)<br /><br />I got tired of the mess of the blade and wanted to try an electric, but I wasn't prepared to spend a lot of money on this experiment.<br /><br />First of all. The instructions say give it three weeks minimum to adjust to the new system. They're serious. My first few shaves were very discouraging, slow, uncomfortable, uneven, and I was left with red irritated skin under my chin.<br /><br />I tried various pre-shaves and aftershaves. By three weeks, I saw large improvements, but I still wasn't sure. It's seven weeks, now, and I'm very impressed. I get a quick close and comfortable shave, and It's still improving. I'm glad I made the switch.<br /><br />FYI<br /><br /> - I only shave twice a week<br /> - My whiskers are pretty coarse and heavy<br /> - I settled on soaking my face with hot water then applying liquid hand soap as my pre-shave routine. It works really well to make the razor glide over my skin.<br /><br /> - I use Bulldog After shave Balm but am feeling the need for it less and less(I hadn't used aftershave almost ever with the blade)<br /><br />------<br />Update:<br />It's now ten weeks, and I gave up on this razor. The comfort is good, and, I can get a very close shave, but it takes 20 minutes. I don't have the patience. I'm ordering a Braun foil shaver. I hope it can handle the stubble better.
  27. Great quality! Doesn't pull hair, gives nice shave.
  28. I had a Norelco 7140 earlier, and that stopped working after being used for over 4 years. This was the replacement, and I think it works a bit better than the previous one that I had. It's definitely lighter, and the battery life is great. I have been using it for about 3 weeks right now on a single charge, and it's still going strong and shaving well. The washability is a nice feature too.<br /><br />**Update July 2014 ** 1 year on, and it's still going great after being used daily. I guess the battery life may be down to about 2 weeks instead of the 3 weeks I wrote originally, but otherwise just like new.
  29. I like that it runs longer between charges. An earlier model that I had for years, the charge did not last as long. I still get the great shave I expected with this model too.
  30. My bad ...... you buy cheap; you get cheap. Should have spent a little more for their best razor. The old adage &#34;you get what you paid for&#34; comes to mind.
  31. My Norelco arrived 2 days earlier than the estimated date which was a welcome surprise. I have not used an electric shaver since the 70's when I received one as a gift. Apparently, the technology from those days just didn't cut the mustard and I was back to using a blade just a few short months later. I had never really considered going back to an electric shaver until I was forced to undergo carotid artery surgery which left a nasty scar from my jawbone to near my collarbone. I can't express the challenge of trying to get a blade close to that sensitive area not to mention I suffered some nerve damage on the surrounding scar tissue as well, adding to the painful task.<br /><br />Reading through many of the reviews on a number of different Norelco models, I settled with this particular razor and I can't tell you enough of how pleased I am with my purchase. This PT730 actually shaves better than a blade and those tough areas are now a breeze to whisk over. I've gone for several days without a shave and this model does not discriminate against the length of the whiskers. The added pop-up trimmer is very efficient in trimming my sideburns and moustache to boot.<br /><br />While the instruction booklet discusses a break-in period and possible facial irritation during the adjustment time, I have not been affected in the least and there is no pulling effect felt at all, just a smooth comfortable shave. Clean up is a snap and the convenience of cordless operation makes this Norelco a product I would highly recommend!
  32. I don't know about you but my electric razors seem to last three or four years and then it's time to toss them. This is the case for the replacement I currently and. It was almost identical to this new one. The batteries would not hold their charge and as one knows replacing any parts in this type razor cost more than a new one. Even the rotary blades wills et you back almost as much as a new razor. I researched all of the Norelco razor and found you can spend a lot of money for the upper end models. Im opted to stay closest to the bottom and just continue to tossing them as they wear out. This one does a good job of shaving mainly because the unit and the blades are still new.i
  33. I have had norelco's in the past. This razor lives up to the expectations I expected.<br />Plus, the razor is extremely quiet. It holds a good charge.<br />Highly satisfied!
  34. United Airlines had my luggage, which someone rifled through and stole my 10 year old Norelco razor, of all things. I replaced it at my own cost, this was the least expensive one Amazon had, I guess you get what you pay for....
  35. This is a decent enough product for the price, but it doesn't give a shave as close as a razor.
  36. I can't really compare it to other electric razors, but it definitely doesn't cut as close as a manual one. However, once you get used to tightening your skin as you go around I'd say it does a good job. I wanted to go electric because I was tired of having to buy replacement heads so often; furthermore, it seemed like my skin was getting irritated. With this one I feel like it gets the job done without the irritation. Sometimes I have to go over areas a few times before it cuts the hair.<br /><br />I would like to point out that the cover for the blade broke off one of it's attachment pieces very early on, though I don't remember how I managed to do that, maybe I put it on incorrectly and tried to force it.
  37. As allways the best razor brand available. With normal care this razor will last thru at least two sets of cutting heads.
  38. Its my first electric razor, however i cant have a decent shave with this one, i prefer the classic razors like the gillette ones.<br /><br />I wouldnt recomend this product.
  39. Norelco razor they are very good product I have owed a few in the pass years . works great gives a good shave.
  40. I've found this product to be much better than my old foil shaver. Sure it's more bulky with the 3 rotating blades but I find it does get quite a nice shave...just not as close as my foil shaver.<br />The ability to run it under water clears out the blades and such easily however I find it hard to dry so I tend to use a brush and compressed air before all that.<br /><br />Run time is more than enough, didn't even have to charge it while I was on vacation for 6 days and even then, I didn't pass 50% use.<br /><br />Overall, a great little shaver for the price, although I think the wet/dry model would have been a slightly better choice...just more money for that.
  41. I use this razor daily which replaced a Norelco 6863XL At the time I thought there was nothing better than the 6863XL which I and a local small appliance repair shop struggled with to keep it running. Finally, parts were no longer available and I was forced to move on to a replacement razor. After careful research and reading of reviews, I thought I would try the PT730. Initially, the PT 730 seemed to me as running slow. However, when I got used to the razor and my beard settled in with it, it's undoubtedly the best razor I have used in years. For the cost coupled with the ease of cleaning the unit, you just cannot beat it! Highly recommend it!! .

But the experience with PT730 is altogether different. I have a very rough beard that grows pretty fast, yet with a fully grown beard the performance of this shaver is amazing. Gentle effortless rotations on the beard with PT730 is enough for a smooth shave. The shaving experience itself is quite amazing, easy on the skin and absolutely no pinching or cuts.

  77. I have had this shaver about 9 months now. I needed to replace my old Norelco Spectra razor which, unfortunately, died. I wanted a razor that did not cost hundreds of dollars, after all, all I wanted was a decent shave. ( I didn't need to impress myself with a fancy, expensive one.) I also wanted one that was as easy to clean and maintain and did not require monthly $$ for this and that. I like the triple head concept of the old Norelco and the shave it gave, but I decided to try a moderately priced Braun, just for a change. After a few shaves, I sent it back. It was like trying to shave with a 2x4 in your hand. Plus, the shaving felt dangerous. Anyway, I compared all Noreclo models in this class and their reviews and chose the PT730. Having used it for a number of months, here's what I have discovered for MY shaving.<br /> Pros: Light and fairly quiet. Better than the old Spectra. Shaves close enough if you give it time and patience. Convenient to clean, and this is what I really like the most about it. You just pop the head up, put it under running water, shake it off, and you are done til next time. I 'd buy it again just based on this, maybe.<br /> Cons: Feels too light and cheap. The Spectra felt solid, like it would last. The shave takes a lot of patience and reruns, pulling the face, coming back, and mowing it down. It only takes about 4 minutes per shave, but I get impatient having to redo and redo facial areas. It seems the old Spectra shaved no closer, but was quicker. Finally, the razor just does not seem to have enough power to really do the job in less time. It charges fine, but after the first two shaves, you are always wondering if the recharge light is going to come on soon. After a week of shaves, you wonder if it will get you through the shave.<br />Overall, a decent shaver. If you have a heavy beard, (mine is probably medium), patience is a requirement to own this little face mower. I really like its convenience, but I am notsure if I would buy it again. I just wish Noreclo had a shaver in this class with a little MORE POWER.
  78. Good razor if you can get it on sale. Only thing I don't like is that the head pops open when I travel causing the captured hair to go all over my travel bag.
  79. If I were to purchase another electric shaver, I would have spent a little more money on a different one. My experience with this one has not been too great. Often I go over the same spot several times which will irritate my skin and leave redness. At the time I spent around 50 dollars to purchase this shaver. Pros; it does shave for the most part, fairly easy to clean, long battery life. Cons; I consider the shaver to be big, misses hairs, irritates skin. Yes even after long term use. I am out of the return period or I would send it back. It is just collecting dust now.
  80. My birthday present from my son for the past several years has been his getting a haircut and a shave. That's right, once a year, whether he needs it or not. Through the winter he looks like a cross between a mountain man and a yeti. I ordered this razor for him with a small spark of hope that he might use it a couple of times a year. He says it is lightweight, comfortable to hold, runs quietly, and he spent about 45 minutes using it without the cord in an attempt to bushwhack his extensive beard. It did not run out of power before he ran out of beard, which speaks highly for the battery charge! The razor comes with a charging plug, cleaning brush, and snap-on blade cover, and was easy to clean under running water.
  81. Summary: The PT 730 provides a decent shave and convenient features like the ability to rinse out the heads with running water. It looks nice and handles well. However, it's results don't feel any better to me than the lower priced Norelco 7310XL.<br /><br />Pros:<br />* Nicely styled with classic Norelco triple rotary heads.<br />* The highly polished shaving heads are very smooth and comfortable.<br />* It is easy to clean with a pushbutton opening for the shaving heads that allows them to be cleaned out with a puff of air or a stream of water.<br />* Very good battery life (over two weeks for me, but then again, I am an Asian ...).<br />* Comes with charger, cleaning brush, and AC charger.<br /><br />Cons:<br />* It's a little longer than my old 7310XL, and the only reason seems to be that the tail end of this one is more pointed to make it look more sleek.<br />* The patter on the shaving heads is such that although it is slightly smoother than my previous Norelco, it also takes longer to shave. Specifically, the shaving heads are a combination of tiny holes and slots whereas the older shavers have just slots. The result is slightly more comfort but definitely more time to get the job done. I'd personally rather be done faster since the old shaver was not UNcomfortable. This one is just slightly more silky feeling.<br />* It costs more than the still available 7310XL. About 1.6 times.<br /><br />Conclusion:<br />If someone gives you one of these, great! Nice shaver. If you are going to go out and buy one, I would get the 7310XL and save the money. I gave it four stars because I do like the shave, and I feel that there would be many who would value the slight edge in comfort over the 25% faster shave of the 7310XL.
  82. I have been using the 7310 Norelco for the past year, but this one seems to glide more easily/smoothly, probably due to the new HQ8 heads. Combine that with the ease of being able to rinse it after use and 140 minutes of shaving on a charge and it is a winner.

  91. I've had this razor for about a month and am not impressed. In order to get the closest shave they promise from this razor you must allow \\"3 weeks for your hair and skin to adjust.\\" Meanwhile, you have to go to work looking like a half-shaven bum (because if you shave with anything else, according to Philips, your facial hair won't adjust properly). After the mandatory three week wolf-person phase, I am still not getting a close shave and have to go over the same spot relentlessly to catch every hair. All in all, I am extremely disappointed that I wasted so much money, time and irritated skin on this. I think I'll just give up on shaving, move to Portland and grow a beard.
  92. I can't be too critical of this shaver, because I haven't used anything better. That said, I haven't used much, and I've stuck mostly to blades over the years.<br /><br />I'm not just a face-shaver but also a head-shaver, so I've really put this unit through the paces doing both. It does the job, I'm happy to say, and it does it better than my previous Norelco model (was sort of their lower-level model last year).<br /><br />I don't think any shaver is going to get as close as a blade. For me, it gets my face about to the point that shaving WITH the grain, with a blade, would do. That's good enough, as I don't have heavy facial hair.<br /><br />It does well enough on my head, too, although it takes a long time. I usually spend 15 minutes shaving my head and face daily. It doesn't get my head hair anywhere near as close to the skin as a blade would, obviously.<br /><br />I like this for the convenience. It seems to be easier, and probably cheaper, than using blades on my head, and it's definitely easier on my face than blades. It irritates my skin less both places. The trimmer is handy and nice, too. However, it doesn't get as close to the skin as a blade. I had sort of hoped it would.
  93. This is actually my first electric razor and I LOVE it. Used it every day for 2 years now with no problems and also still no need to replace blades. Charger works in Asia and EU as well.   96. For facial hair, it cuts really close, but sometimes have to shave over once with a disposable razor blade to rid of the very few strands of shortened hair that remain, in order to keep my face extra smooth. If in a rush, and/or not in the mood to gel up my face and use the blade, I use the trimmer on the back of the shaver to cut most of the remaining hairs off. I use it to tidy up my beard while also keeping it low, to keep my mustache a certain length, and to shave my sides off, once a week. Each session takes about 3 - 5 minutes. As for head hair, I have not used it to cut as close to the scalp as possible. I do use it to keep my hair low though (usually between 5mm to 10mm). One minor problem I have with shaving my head with this shaver is since my hair is very curly, after one pass around my whole head I have to clean out the shaver, or else the cut hair will curl around the blades, causing them to spin slower and cut inefficiently. Sometimes my hair gets stuck between a few grooves, which slightly extends the time to clean. To reduce the time spent stopping to clean the shaver out, I try not to go more than 2 days without shaving my head. Each session takes about 10 - 15 minutes, not including the time it takes to clean out the item (which would double the time). When kept clean, the Philips Norelco PT730/41 Shaver 3500 cuts hair very well. If completely dead, it takes about 8 hours to fully charge, as indicated on the box. I usually charge it while I sleep after I've used it for about four 5-10 minute sessions. I've had this product for about 2 and a half months now and it works the same as it did when I first used it.

  106. I had given my two sons Norelco shavers similar to this one that had been reviewed well, but they both complained about them. I was happy when I had a chance to try one myself, but I have to echo their lack of enthusiasm. This product doesn't seem particularly well designed. It's not very ergonomic, at least in my hand. The big problem is that it seems to resist the purpose for which it was intended: delivering a smooth, close shave. I tried it on my legs and underarms, and the criticisms my sons had were repeated for me: it resolutely left behind longer hairs, requiring going over and over the area (ouch!) and it seemed to have trouble with thicker, coarser hair. Skin and hair are pretty much the same story, whether on the face or legs, and if my legs were any indication, a truly close shave could take much longer than most people have to spare in the morning. The first time I tried it, it was incredibly irritating on my upper leg area, but the instructions tell you to expect that. Subsequent shaves were not as unsightly, but they were basically fruitless. I'm back to using my Gillette Mach 3, unless I ever have a chance to try a Braun or other European brand. If you are a young boy just sprouting a beard, this may work for you. Otherwise, I would suggest looking elsewhere. I give it 3-1/2 stars because the heads do float nicely (if ineffectively) over contours, it is cordless, and it rinses clean.
  107. Bought for my 93yr old father. Gives a great shave!y father loves it!
  108. Softening the beard with warm water first is the key to any good shave. After lightly drying my face, I find the shave is a smooth process with no pulling. I do the circular patterns as recommended, but I also use the shaver like a razor on my lower neck. For extra smoothness, you can also glide the razor down the jaw line with the edge of two rotors which acts like a straight edge without the cuts. The shaver is light weight which is a change from previous shavers I have used. It cleans up well under water and dries fairly quickly. A shave takes about seven minutes. The built in trimmer is ok for most needs. I rinse after the shave with warm water and clean up any missed spots. It is a quality product and I would buy it for a gift.
  109. Compared with the Norelco that I have from about 10 yrs ago, this one just doesn't have the 'heft' and good feel about it.   122. This razor came in a plain white box, instead of the standard company packaging. Despite being a new model, it's very much similar to other Norelco razors long since released. In my humble opinion, Philips Norelco 7310 (also a basic model, but a little older) is better. Pros -For the money, you get the standard quality all Norelco razors offer, and if there's one thing that can be said about this product, it's the quality. -Features such as cordless shaving, quick charging, comfortable precision based shaving, and an attractive design. Cons -In comparison to older basic models, particularly the 7310 model, this razor tends to get a little too loud during the shaving. -The on/off button, which lights up in green in the 7310 model, is pretty much colorless in this model, blending into the blackness of the overall design, and making things a little boring (and too basic). Overall, though, it's pretty much similar to other Norelco models. If, like me, you already purchased a Norelco razor in the past, you can get a little nitpicky with this model. If, on the other hand, this is your first Norelco razor, you are likely to be satisfied.

The shave isn't as close as i expected but i saw a review saying the same thing and he updated it saying it broke in and about 2 - 3 weeks.<br /><br /> The shave is very close now. I shaved 3 times so far. Had a 5'0 clock shadow, It was great. But I am waiting for the closer shave. Or forgot to mention no burn or rash has happened yet like my old one but i think that was due to the head not being replaced.<br /><br />The Bottom Line: I would definitely recommend this, however my dad tried to snatch it so i bought him a cheaper model for 30 - 40 bucks, Not sure witch model. And i feel like his is the same but cheaper $<br /><br />Great shave.
  127. Offers a close shave, much closer than my older Norelco (model unknown) which stopped working altogether for an unknown reason, just wouldn't turn on. The shaving was painless, close/smooth and extremely quiet so I rate this as great, however the power cord and connecting the cord to the razor is very weak. It is much lighter, and feels fragile compared to my older model.

  129. Nice razor. It doesn't run very fast, but the shave is good. I use a blade in the shower once a week or so, which may be helpful. As someone else noted, if you try to shake the water off, the cutter head my fly off, causing me to call upon my Sailor vocabulary. I do like that I can pop the top and put it under the tap to clean it. The battery seems to last long enough, and the power cord isn't a pain. Pretty happy, so far. If it doesn't last five years, I'll be grumpy. You'll know it.<br /><br />My first electric was a Remington wall plug, and it lasted a decade or more. As I started liking shaving in the car on the way to work or after the gym, I went through a few Norelco cordless over a 20 year period. When the batteries went bad, I just pitched 'em. Usually I'd repl the cutters a couple of times before the batteries STB.<br /><br />The last one didn't last as long or shave as well as I wanted, so I got a Braun, which lasted maybe five years before the batteries went south. I replaced the cutting head every 18 months as recommended, but it never gave a great shave. So I'm back to Norelco. Yo, I tore the Braun down to parade rest - some kind of weird batteries, dang it. I'll fiddle with it, but probably won't use it again. Wow, is it a fine piece of engineering!

(Now I know to buy only corded or corded/cordless shavers,) So I got my third unit, at no added cost. That lasted until late January 2015 and the same old &#34;no charge&#34; problem again. Well I've just thrown out this Norelco shaver and have ordered a Braun shaver that works when plugged in, even if the battery is dead.   189. Philips PT730 Razor<br /><br />This cordless razor was tested on whiskers that were used to an old fashioned blade shaver. All test shaving has been done on dry skin. No gel or hot water was applied to the skin.<br /><br />The razor works very well, resulting in a nice smooth shave with no risk of cuts.<br /><br />There is no burn after shaving. The razor does much better than a manual razor when it comes to navigating scars and cuts. Shave right over the scar with no damage done.<br /><br />It takes a little longer to shave since it is not as easy to see via the shaving cream where you have shaved and where you have not shaved.<br /><br />The razor is easy to clean.
  190. The Norelco PT730 shaves very closely. In comparison with a 10-year old Norelco model (fitted with brand new blades), it leaves the face much smoother. This is probably due to the modifications that have been made to the circular screens that contact the skin. The ability to rinse the shaver under running water is a great convenience. Here are a couple of tips for maintenance: *As recommended in the product manual, do rinse the blade assembly and parts where the hair collects after each use. After rinsing and gently shaking to remove dripping water, leave the head assembly open to air dry. Be careful when shaking the unit, as the head assembly is held by a friction spring, and can easily be shaken apart from the razor body. *While it is possible to disassemble the head assembly for brush cleaning, the reassembly is not as straightforward as was the case with earlier models, so you want to avoid having to do this until necessary. These razors have come down in price over the years, have a better battery (lithium-ion vs. nickel-cadmium), and do a better job. If you have an older Norelco razor, you might consider replacing it with the PT730.
  191. This is my favorite shaver. Why? The HQ8 shaving heads, I like rinsing the shaver, and it's very quiet. The HQ8 shaving heads are much more comfortable than the Speed XL HQ9 heads and do a better job. I switched to electric shaving years ago. Was hooked after the first shave. I haven't cut myself shaving in 20 years. I started with a standard Panasonic, then the Panasonic Linear, Norelco Speed XL(until it died about 15 years), Braun, and now back to Norelco with the 3500. The Braun is to loud. Very loud! I couldn't take it anymore. Used it a year and a half. The Norelco does a better job cutting longer hair when I don't shave a couple of days and does a better job on the neck. Compared to the Braun it seems the motor is wimpy. Don't be fooled. This shaver cuts well. My beard is like barbed wire. Also, I want to mention something I feel is important about skin irritation. I've very sensitive skin and I noticed the lifters on the shaving head are brass and were causing me irritation. I took the liberty of removing them. They are not needed. Very easy to remove. I'm making no sacrifices removing them. The shave is just as close. Just use a pair of needle nose pliers and a jewelers visor so you can see what your doing. I did this when I used the Speed XL. I love the Norelco shaver without the lifters. It's really not difficult to remove them. Also, this shaver does not come with a travel pouch nor a charging stand. I contacted Norelco through a chat window on the support site and they are sending me a pouch and charging stand free of charge! Stellar customer service! If you are switching to an electric shaver for the first time you may have some irritation because your skin is raw from blade shaving. Give it time and you will never go back.
  192. shaver came in good time and in new out of the box shape. shaves clean and smooth. everything works. easy to clean. so far so good. i'm happy.
  193. I used Norelco shavers long ago. I can't remember exactly why I stopped, but it probably had something to do with the my belief that it is impossible to get a blade-close shave with an electric. Then, one day in December I realized that I am the only one who knows the difference. Who cares if the blade shave is closer? And, if I had a nickle for every time I got up too late to use the foamy crap and then clean up to go over the missed spots again (skipped shaving altogether on those days).... Well, I got to looking at my old Norelco, (battery shot) and said, &#34;what the heck, let's give a new one a try&#34;. I'm glad I did. The first couple of shaves were not anything to write home about, but after the 3rd & 4th, they just got better. Now, I'm just as fast, probably faster than with the shaving cream and blade, I can quickly see if I need to hit a spot again, I never nick myself (OMG! What a time saver that is!) and, I don't know the difference in closeness til some time in the afternoon. Then, yes, there is a bit more stubble than before. Nobody notices. This morning I got up late, heck, brought it along and shaved at work! Battery life great, super quiet, cleans up well under the faucet! Wow! Give this shaver a try, you won't be dissapointed.
  194. i alreday bought 2 for my parent it's good things whith a good shiping time i very like it !
  195. In these modern times, where chaos and political upheaval are all around us, it's nice to know you can still find little islands of stability and sanity in the world.<br /><br />This razor is one of those islands. It's very simple, really; you push a button and it whirrs. You rub the front bit on your face and it makes hair go away.<br /><br />It's not brilliant about it. Sometimes, you have to rub the round bits on the same spot on your face more than once to make all the hair disappear. If you're looking for the high-tech, GPS-guided cruise missile of hair removal, this isn't it. But it is cheap, and it works, and it makes a satisfactory mechanical noise while the spinny bits whisk away unwanted hair. Really, what more do you want in a razor?
  196. Coming from a similar Philips Norelco razor that was a few years old, my husband was surprised at how much better this razor is. Among the improvements:<br /><br />- The battery lasts much longer and charges incredibly fast<br />- The indicator light for low-battery, charging, fully charged, etc. actually makes sense<br /><br />Given this model's very reasonable price point, it would likely be a nice upgrade for anyone who has an older model and is ready to replace it.

  199. Out of the box this razor felt much better than my previous $25 Remington. It had a good 5 year run but was beginning to keep short battery life so it was time for a replacement. The first thing I noticed about the PT730 was the appearance. The buttons are cleaner, tolerances on parts are tighter and it seems to be an all around better product. Right out of the box I was able to fire it up and shave without having to wait for a charge. My initial thoughts were \\"OUCH!\\" My Remington was known to pull if the hair was long enough so I didn't take any chances with this one. I used the Pop-up Trimmer to knock them down to a reasonable level before using the razor. I also noticed much more of a \\"razor\\" feel, as thought i was shaving instead of getting a haircut (as I did with my Remington). It was a bit of a trick to figure out which direction to push/pull with this razor to get some of the longer hairs to cut. I would say this was the only downfall of the PT730 and may be the case with all Norelcos (assumption) After a few minutes, I now have the closest shave I've ever gotten from an electric razor. My wife even said she doesn't remember ever seeing me \\"this clean shaven\\". I purchased an over-priced fancy $150 Norelco in the past and didn't feel it cut any better than the $25 Remington so I returned it. The PT730 is definitely a cut above (or should i say shave above) the Remington. Hopefully this one will last many years and continue its perfect cut.

  207. I've used Norelco shavers for ... at least 4 decades. My latest shaver gave up the ghost after a decade. I ordered the PT730 as a compromise between frills (battery indicator) and features (pop up trimmer). The special pricing by Amazon was a strong inducement.<br /><br />My first impression is that the shaver is built very cheaply for the price. It is lighter, possibly owing to the switch from heavier Ni-Cd batteries. The cut is less efficient than had from prior Norelco shavers, possibly because the motor seems to spin at a slower speed. I suppose the razor is OK, but its definitely not the best.<br /><br />ADDENDUM<br /><br />I find that I have to use a regular blade every week or so to \\"catch up\\" with overgrowth. After a year or so, I'd have to conclude that I'm not impressed with this razor.

  217. I am just getting out of the Army and as such I wanted to change from a blade to an electric razor because of skin irritation. I knew that I wouldn't be getting as close of a shave as I normally would get with a blade, using an electric razor, but I wasn't really too concerned with it as I thought it would be close enough. Well I was wrong about that, or should I say I was wrong in thinking that this shaver would get the job done. While it does a decent job at getting the really thin short hairs on my upper cheeks, anything from under my nose to my chin and neck look like I didn't even bother to shave at all! And this is after at least 5 to 7 minutes of using the electric razor over and over on my face and neck! So unless you hardly get any facial hair at all, (as in you only need to shave once or twice a week and still look clean shaven all week), then I'd highly recommend staying away from this product!
  218. I HADN'T used a electric razor for years , so I was concerned that it might not work all that well. It was much better than I could have expected.
  219. Works great, rarely have to shave like it is, cuts close and smooth with no razor burn, long battery life.
  220. I really like this unit. It is very quiet and my son who I use it on doesn't seem to mind it. It gives a close shave so<br />overall it was worth the extra money.

  223. The Norelco PT730 does not give a particulary close shave. Not unusual for an electric razor. However, the real problem is cleaning. When the head is opened the rotary shaving heads become loose as does the retainer. Reassembly is quite delicate and difficult and easily done incorrectly. One doesn't need this complication in order to shave. A twin blade razor costing less tnan ten dollars does a better job and has no moving parts.
  224. I bought this as a replacement for my existing shaver. My existing shaver works well but the charge does not last long. I wish this company would design their product so that users could swap out the batteries. The new shaver works well but the batteries are still not user replaceable.
  225. Good products. Doesn't hurt the skin, shaves long hair without trimming it first, good trimmer. Easily washable. But... It needs a little to many strokes to shave and doesn't shave close...

  236. It does not give as good of a shave as the older model Philip Norelco razor I have..unfortunately, that one, which I have had for many years just wouldn't hold a charge very long any more, so I decided to try this one. Liked the old one better.
  237. I recently purchased the PT730. I have owned a Norelco 5842 XL for 26 years. It has dropped down to about 1 week of use per charge from the 6 weeks it was for many years. I am only on my second set of shaving heads. I just got tired of charging it weekly. The old razor outperforms the PT730 in every way. The only advantage the new one has is that it is lighter and quieter and that is mostly due to it having a marginal motor. It has no more than half the power of the old razor. I was also surprised to find that it doesn't shave as closely as my 15 year old cutting heads. Maybe things have to wear in a bit for optimum closeness.<br /><br />Fortunately for me, the PT730 does an adequate job because I don't have very heavy whiskers. For those who have light to medium whiskers, this shaver will be fine. If you have manly-man stubble I would suggest looking for something with more power. If you require a very close shave, look elsewhere as well.<br /><br />UPDATE - I have had the razor for a month now and I feel obligated to up my rating from 3 stars to 5 stars. The heads or my face broke in after 3 or 4 days and I am now getting a very nice shave. It went 4 weeks on the first charge being used 5 days a week. I went 3 days without shaving once and when I did resume, there was no pulling or tugging at all. Very nice. I still find the motor to be weak, but it seems to do the job for me, and I really like the light weight and low noise. I would still be hesitant if you grow really heavy whiskers, but to all others I say buy this one.
  238. I recently started using an electric razor again after not using one for several years. It did take a couple weeks to adjust to this shaver, which was uncomfortable at first but the owners manual said to expect that for the first couple weeks or so. After about a month of using it, I am very happy with the PT730. It is lightweight, can be cleaned under the sink, and works well. I have moderately thick hair and this razor has no problem dealing with it. Obviously there are more expensive razors out there and you get what you pay for, but this one is a good compromise between the entry level model and the upscale $100+ models. I'm happy with this and will continue to use it until it stops working.
  239. Great, It's lighter, quieter, and gives a better shave than my last Norelco. It also has a trimmer built in
  240. It's the small things with this one. A cover to protect the blades actually helps when it sits in the bathroom, a location with water flying everywhere, it's nice to make sure the blades stay nice and protected. It's very easy to clean, disassemble, and reassemble again afterward. For just a little bit of stubble, I haven't had any problem with it at all, and if that's what you need it for, at this price, I would say it's a sure buy.<br /><br />On the other hand, it doesn't deal with thick hair very well. The blades are fine, but it will pull and tug, and generally not create the best experience. Unless you press fairly hard, it can also miss the occasional smaller hairs. No big deal, but certainly annoying.<br /><br />I should also note that being able to use it without it being plugged in is fantastic. I lived in a dorm room for a while, and there were no outlets inside. Guess what this ended up replacing? Overall a solid razor, and one of the best electric razors for the price out there if I had to pass a guess.
  241. Have had this item now for over a month. Have only recharged it twice, in spite of daily shaving.<br />VERY quiet.<br />Easy to clean.<br />Best razor I've owned, regardless of price.
  242. This is the third time we have purchased this product. Each time we are more pleased than the last. The shave is close and smooth and the battery lasts a long time without recharging. It's perfect for long weekends, etc when there is no need to worry about recharging.
  243. With mixed feelings and desperation I purchased this product.<br /><br />I read several reviews, and although it seemed that it was a good buy, many of the reviews I found cautioned that it wasn't the best for heavier facial hair. Since the price was right, I made the purchase. True to the other reviews, I found that it does lack a little in the cutting department, but does not fail completely. Allow me to elaborate.<br /><br />One - two days worth of full stubble is not that big of a deal. I shave almost every morning, and found that this razor did a pretty good job taking care of about 97% of the hair. I did have to go in with a disposable to hit around the sideburns, but I expected to do so from the get-go.<br /><br />Two & 1/2 - Four days worth of stubble is pretty spotty. Don't get me wrong, there's no grinding of the tiny motors, or smoke coming from the device when using it under these conditions... but I did notice that it missed a hair here, and a hair there. Actually, missing a few noticeable ones all over the neck.<br /><br />So in the long run, If you're shaving with it every day, then, YES, this is a great razor. I have not noticed any irritation or problems from using it, it gets under and around the nose area very well, and it holds a pretty good charge. But if you're looking to use it once a week between a lot of growth, you may wish to look elsewhere.
  244. Let me start off by saying that the purpose of buying a rotary razor is for shaving my head. I am a bald male who prefers not to use a razor blade across my head and instead enjoys the comfort of using an electric razor as an alternative.<br /><br />Norelco has always been my choice of rotary razor, and for years I have been using various models. The most recent model was their Speed-XL series (with HQ9 replacement heads) which are expensive but well made. After owning this particular model for the past 3 years, I decided it was time to replace the unit.<br /><br />I found out that buying a new Norelco razor is not an easy chore. If you are reading this review, you probably have been knocked silly by the sheer amount of different Norelco razors that the company sells through Amazon. One has no clue (outside of the reviews) which is the newer models or which one is superior to the other. As of this review, I think the PowerTouch razors are the new line of offerings this year. They include the PT720, PT730, AT810 and AT830.<br /><br />My first choices were the AT810 and AT830. Thought it would be great to have a Norelco that I could use wet in the shower. However, I stopped dead in my tracks when I realized that those two razors could only be operated on battery power. Mind you, I had no intention of plugging in the razor and walking into the shower with it -- and I am certain Norelco disabled the ability to do this just on safety ethics. However, from experience I have learned that the batteries in these razors become less and less efficient over the years of ownership and I would much rather use it corded at home and save the battery for travel.<br /><br />The PT730 became the obvious next best choice for me though I was concerned by some of the reviews that cited it as being cheaply built.<br /><br />Having used this razor for the past two days, I can tell you a few things about it....<br /><br />First, if you are coming from an older, more expensive Norelco you will immediately notice that the PT730 does indeed feel cheap. It's a basic no-frills razor with none of the bells-and-whistles of the more expensive choices. But you know what? I wasn't in the mood to spend more than $50 for a rotary razor and I got exactly what I expected.<br /><br />The huge surprise came when I began shaving my head. The Norelco managed to provide an exceptional close shave with little effort. Unlike my older Norelco, I did not have to make multiple passes over the same area to get a smooth, clean shave. Suffice to say, I am very happy with this purchase and I think you will be too.elco you will immediately notice that the PT730 does indeed feel cheap. It's a basic no-frills razor with none of the bells-and-whistles of the more expensive choices. But you know what? I wasn't in the mood to spend more than $50 for a rotary razor and I got exactly what I expected.<br /><br />The huge surprise came when I began shaving my head. The Norelco managed to provide an exceptional close shave with little effort. Unlike my older Norelco, I did not have to make multiple passes over the same area to get a smooth, clean shave. Suffice to say, I am very happy with this purchase and I think you will be too.

  298. I'd used a Remington foil shaver for years. When the foils needed replacing (expensive), I looked for an alternative. Choose the Norelco even though I'd shied away from rotary shavers before. Walmart had a Norelco (lower price/features) on Fathers' Day sale. Searched reviews here and was pleasantly surprised. Works like a dream, smooth shave, quiet operation, water clean-up, and fast charging. It did take about a month for my face to get used to the new shaver but then it's faster and (I think) shaves smoother than the Remington.<br /><br />Only 1 feature needs improvement, so I would rate this shaver 4 1/2 stars: The sideburn trimmer swivels up rather than Remington's which slides up. Because of the hinge on the Norelco trimmer, you can only drag it down on your face; you cannot move it up & down, it wants to swivel back down if you do.<br /><br />Overall, I recommend this shaver despite the trimmer issue.

  302. This was purchased as a replacement for the AT830 model I returned to Amazon. This unit is capable of both corded (plugged in) and cordless operation where the AT830 is strictly and charge and use cordless model. The PT730 provides a good close cut - no burn or irriation noticed (although I have used Norelco electrics for nearly 17 years so I am used to them). This is my fourth Norelco and they seem to keep improving them and adding features as the years go by. This one is smaller and lighter in weight than my previous one - probably due to the switch in battery power (lithium ion as opposed to nickel cadium). Blades are not quite as sturdy as previous models but still get the job done. All in all I am very happy and the extra good news is this model was nearly $30 cheaper than the AT830. Go figure!! I would highly recommend this as very versatile electric razor.

Judging by the reviews, which are largely positive, I just got unlucky. I never have given a 1 star rating before, but wanted to put this out there to warn people not so much not to buy it, but to save your packaging material (which I did not) in case you have to send it back.   315. I have been using this razor for about two weeks and I am very satisfied with its performance. Although it is of a less-substantial and less-durable design than the three-head Norelco shaver I owned many years ago, it is more than adequate for cleaning up the stubble on my face not covered by my beard and moustache. With just a quick pass over those areas, the three-head design really gives a close shave. My beard grows fast but is of average thickness and has a normal &#34;resistance to shaving quotient.&#34; The flip-up shaing heads are easy to clean with the provided brushes, but I am very careful not to brush too vigorously for fear of breaking some vital plastic part therein. The charging system (AC cord with built-in step-down transformer) is easy to use and packs up neatly in the storage pouch I provided. I would say that I am not a typical user in that I only use the shaver for touch-ups every other day. For that reason, I probably won't have to replace the cutting heads assembly within one year as suggested by the manufacturer. If you want a more durable, more powerful and longer-lasting shaver (which THIS model is decidedly NOT), you should go for one of the more expensive high-end shavers. As with most electrically powered appliances, you get what you pay for.
  316. Very smooth shave no nicks. Get Electra shave lotion. Gets a better shave. Very happy the electric razor. Follow charging hints.
  317. Previous to this purchase I owned a Norelco 3405LC electric shaver for the last 15 years or so. The PT730 is a FAR superior shaver. The 3405LC caused &#34;razor burn&#34; far too frequently on my neck if I skipped shaving for several days; it was noisy, and also required multiple passes to effectively shave.<br /><br />In stark contrast the PT730 is quiet, the rotors swivel to fit my face/neck contours, and it shaves with a couple circular passes over an area. Wish the 3405LC had broken sooner!!!.

  344. I had the luck to find this shaver on Amazon Vine, and since I use shavers, this was perfect for me! I've previously bought a Philips Norelco 7310, [[ASIN:B001AJ6YS2 Philips Norelco 7310 Men's Shaving System]], but to tell you the truth, they're pretty much the same shaver (which isn't a bad thing, mind you). Uses the same heads, has the pop-up trimmer, slightly different contour, but even the cleaning brush is identical.<br /><br />So, what I liked about this.<br />Lithium ion batter is good, which means it won't have problems with frequent use and recharge, and also means you can use as a travel charger, since the battery won't self-discharge too much.<br /><br />Easy to clean. Pop the button on the bottom of the head, and the head/screen flips up (but is still connected to the shaver). This allows you to clean the head and blades without losing or dropping the head. I've dropped the screen a few times using Braun and Remington screen shavers, and have almost cut myself wiping those blades. Shouldn't be a problem with this Norelco shaver.<br /><br />Simple pop-up trimmer. I also use this when I get the stray wiry beard whisker that you just can't fit into the screen to shave off. The pop-up trimmer is a bit loud and vibrates a bit more than I expect, but it works.<br /><br />Not so likes:<br />The brush doesn't attach to the shaver, so you KNOW I'll be losing this brush in a month or two.<br /><br />No pouch/case/bag/anything. Usually, I'd at least get a vinyl bag or plastic case, but here, nothing. Maybe the retail version will come with something.<br /><br />Overall, recommended, especially for its price.<br /><br />There's also the Norelco PT720 [[ASIN:B006GQYSFA Philips Norelco PT720 PowerTouch Rechargeable Cordless Razor, Blue/Silver/Black]], which goes for about 10-15 bucks cheaper, but you lose the pop-up trimmer. And there's always the Norelco 7310, they're still sold at Amazon via Reseller.
  345. Disclaimer: I am reviewing a unit I received for free through the Vine program.<br /><br />This is the best electric shaver I've ever used. And I've been using electric shavers for over 25 years, since the mid 1980's.<br /><br />I used to try other brands with different technologies. People swore by Braun so I got a Braun; in fact I went through several Braun shavers. I thought it was just me, that I was having so much difficulty getting a close comfortable shave quickly.... I thought it was just me, having so much trouble cleaning all the gnarled tangled hair around the blades..... I'd replace the foils but it wouldn't help much, etc. I used to have to use the popup trimmer just because the regular shaver simply would not catch/cut some stubborn hairs.<br /><br />Then I got one of these (I started with the previous model, before getting this newest one). Wow, what a difference! Very close shave, very comfortably, and very quickly.<br /><br />And afterwards, don't even have to scrape, to clean it -- just shake and rinse, and all the hair just falls right out, because of the design; no hair gets tangled in the blades at all, it all falls into the receptacle area, ready to shake out.
  346. Holds a charge longer than any other brand, weeks at a time. Decent shave. Good product. I would recommend giving it a try.
  347. I bought this razor to replace a Remington rotary that although still works perfectly well has to be kept on charge and even then the battery is only good for one shave.<br />Out of the box and charged up the PT730 felt nicer in the hand and was quieter, though the pop up trimmer feels a bit cheap and rattly.<br />Then on to the important bit, shaving. First impression was the lack of glide, it just felt awkward. More importantly was the lack of closeness. OK, this is a different make to my old one and maybe technique could improve the closeness after a bit more use but I persevered for about 10 minutes covering the same areas many times till it was obvious that it wasn't going to get any closer. Out of curiosity I tried then with the old Remington and knew as soon as I heard the cutting noise that I had downgraded to a less efficient razor.

They don't get quite as close as a 3 blade manul razor on the neck, but I haven't found any electric razor that does that area like a razor and shaving cream does. The shave on the rest of my face is excellent though. The battery lasts a long time, I am still running on the first charge, but I only shave every other day due to skin issues. Even with sensitive skin, my face has not been irritated using this razor.

  374. This is my 1st electic shaver in 30+ years of shaving. I've always wanted to try one as an alternative to razor blades and cream. With all of the different types, styles, models, etc. it always overwhelmed me as to what would work the best for me. After doing another round of researching the Norelco PT730 seemed to offer a mix of value and performance based on reviews. After 4 months in the world of electric razoring, I find it works just fine for me. I actually use it everyday where I might only have shaved with a blade every other day if I could get away with it. As I have nothing to compare it to, I am so far pretty happy with the quality and shave I get for the price. I'm on my 1st set of blades and replacements are almost as much as the entire unit, but I'll probably keep using them until it quits me. I'm the same guy who uses a small binder clip on my toothpaste to get every drop, so trust me, I'll get the most out of this razor. The charge seems to last at least a couple of weeks and does have a light on the charger so I know when it is charged (pretty quickly). I bought the companion Norelco QT4000/42 Beard Trimmer and they have two different wall wart chargers (which sort of sucks) but I plug them both in the morning and I'm packing a charge for a couple of weeks.<br /><br />Again- without ever having another electric razor to compare this to, as a cheap first time razor, it works for me.

  398. Just got it. A few shaves in, and it is very comfortable and effective. Too early to tell yet about reliability.
  399. This is my first rotating-head-style shaver. However, I bought it mainly because I finally wanted to have a portable shaver with a lithium battery since my older Panasonic had the usual nickel-cadmium piece of junk.<br /><br />So the shaver does seem to last quite a while on a single charge, though, since it's new, that's to be expected. The biggest issue for me with electric shavers is that my beard is light -- I only need to shave a few times a week -- and my innate laziness about shaving regularly leaves me with isolated stubble that's grown so long it usually folds beneath the foil of a shaver and never gets chopped off. Which forces me to shave with a razor and foam to get back to a clean-shaven face.<br /><br />The rotating-head shaving experience is definitely odd. In particular, I find this shaver isn't especially good at getting stubble just below my nose ... conventional straight-foil shavers seem to do that better. (I've since learned to adjust how I hold the shaver to get that nasally challenged beard.) And, to be honest, I'm not really sure how good it is getting stubble that's grown to a certain length because the shaver's reliability on a single charge has prompted me to shave more often. (Recent experience suggests it *does* do better than my previous shavers at chopping off longer stubble.)<br /><br />Still, I seem to get a half-dozen shaves on a single charge, and the shaver thoughtfully uses the charging light as a warning signal -- ordinarily off when not being charged, it will start to flash when the charge is running low. It's also surprisingly quiet. The first time I used it I was afraid I hadn't charged it long enough, but in the absence of other evidence I've concluded that the rotating-head system appears to require less horsepower from the motor, which means I can actually listen to the radio while shaving in the morning ... a good thing.<br /><br />So, overall, I'm satisfied and can certainly recommend this Philips Norelco to anyone with a light beard like mine. Those with reliable 5-o'clock shadows will have to read someone else's review to know for sure if this shaver is for you.
  400. I've used Norelcos my entire life for shaving and this is my 3rd one. They all work about the same in my opinion except that the newer ones run much longer on one charge. These are reliable workhorses that gets the job done with very low maintenance. I just flip open the top after each shave and dump the contents in my sink. For more thorough cleaning, I'll rinse the head over the sink and dry it off with a towel. Other than that, I change the shaving heads once a year.

  419. I bought this as a gift for my boyfriend. He read the instructions and it mentioned that if you haven't shaved with an electric razor before your skin may be irritated for the first month of use. I feel like &#34;irritated&#34; was kind of an understatement. His skin was really red and splotchy and he was clearly uncomfortable every time he used it, and after two weeks decided it wasn't even worth waiting out the month to see if his skin would adjust. My guess is that everyone will react differently to this product based on skin sensitivity, but I thought it was worth sharing his experience.
  420. This is my third electric shaver in 20 years and the Philips Norelco shavers keep improving in performance. The PT730 is well manufactured, heavy duty and delivers the closest shave yet. I am also happy with the extended warranty that is made possible by registering the shaver online. Overall, a great electric shaver for a relatively low cost.
  421. It was working well when I first got it, I acquired it last summer. Nowadays it won't shave like it used to. It takes a long time to shave the facial hair off.   426. I found over the three-week test period that this razor, although it was nice to my skin, shaved me less and less closely (rather than more and more closely). I contacted Philips through their website/chat and asked to return the razor (they give you 45 days from the date of purchase). They were very friendly and told me the form would be sent to me via email in three days or less. That was nearly three weeks ago. I have contacted them three times since, in every instance getting friendly assurance that the form would be sent out, and I still do no have it. It is obvious that they do not intend to honor their offer. I will never even consider another Philips Norelco razor and will be hesitant about all Philips products.<br /><br />EDIT: I still cannot recommend purchasing this razor but after a couple of months of contacting them and repeatedly explaining that the reason it wasn't returned earlier is that they didn't email me the form I needed to be able to return it--like they repeatedly promised--they finally sent me the right paperwork and I have been reimbursed. I paid $49.95, it cost me ~$10 to return it (they insisted on insured mailing which would have been ~$45 so I ignored that \\"requirement\\") and they sent my original purchase back so it cost me time and about $10 neither of which I will ever get back. If you do decide to purchase this product, make sure you don't use it for the full \\"testing\\" period before deciding whether or not to keep it--make sure you decide in enough time to return it to Amazon and not to Philips.

  433. I wanted to try a cordless electric razor again after shaving with a blade razor for many years. I received the Phillips Norelco PT730/41 for Christmas 2014 and have not gone back to a razor since then. After using this razor for almost seven months, I can say I am pleased with the results. I was initially a little concerned because the motor sounds weaker compared to cordless razors I have used in the past, but I have been able to use this one without ever resorting to pulling out my blade razor to remove stubborn neck hairs. It runs smoothly and my face is nicely shaved when I am done. I am dark-haired, but I don't feel like I need to shave again later that afternoon as I have read in other reviews. Once in the morning has worked fine. My only complaint is that the razor does not seem to hold a charge for as long as it did during the first five months of use. I could let it go for five shaves before recharging it, but after a couple of times of having the razor stall upon turning it on, I now recharge it after three shaves.

  441. I am 55 and so have been shaving for many years. I also have used both razors and electric and on the electric side I have used a foil shaver and now this. This is my favorite shaving experience so far.<br /><br />A razor will give you the closest shave, of course, but electric shavers are convenient and quick. I switched to electric about ten years ago. As to the electric experience, I now enjoy the convenience, lack of a mess, and not needing to always replenish shaving gear (foam or gel and blades).<br /><br />I had a Braun foil shaver, which gave me a good shave, be seemed to be requiring head replacements about every 6 months, which made it very expensive to operate. I saw the good reviews on this shaver and decided to go rotary.<br /><br />First impression was the comfort of the shave. I expected the first week to have some discomfort until my face adjusted to the new feel. But the first time I used it I actually thought that there was some light plastic cover over the heads that I had failed to take off. This machine is extremely comfortable, even if you are not used to a rotary.<br /><br />Next thing I like: As compared to a foil, this rotary shaves longer hairs with fewer passes and thus shaves more quickly than the Braun foil machine. I should note I have a moderate beard. It grows fastest on my neck. This was always a problem with my foil machine. It would take many passes to get the hairs to pop through the foil and into the cutting head. With the rotary, the neck goes really fast.<br /><br />I expected a less close shave than the foil. That is the accepted wisdom. Maybe I am aberrant, but I found a rotary shave to be just as close, if not closer, Than the foil. At least that is true for this machine<br /><br />I REALLY like the ease of cleaning. Just press a button to flip open the head and run under the tap. With my Braun, I had to set it into a noisy cleaning station.<br /><br />In short, great on ease of use, great on quality of shave.<br /><br />UPDATE: I have now had the shaver for almost 2 and one half years. I still like it and would only add that it has passed the durability test. Still holds a charge for many weeks, and I am just now getting ready to replace the head for the first time. Good product.

  444. I got this razor because I had tried everything for the sensitive skin on my neck - Classic Razors, Modern Razors, 'Sensitive Skin Approved' Razors, Special Shaving Cream - nothing worked. I have noticed significantly less bumps on my neck, but I've also noticed if I go more than 2-3 days without shaving I get them as bad as before.   479. I had used my Norelco electric shaver for over 20 years before it finally gave out. I was very happy with it, so I decided to purchase another Norelco and liked the price for the PT730.   481. I have been very pleased with the PT730 after one month. In doing research before purchasing the shaver, I took all the posted reviews, both positive and negative, with a grain of salt. A user's impressions will be based on various factors.<br /><br />1. Type of beard: I consider my beard to be a solid medium to slightly heavy. I have stubble every day and if I don't shave for 2 days, it starts to look grubby. I've had no problems getting a fairly close shave where the skin feels smooth when I run my hand on it afterwards. Daily shaving is my routine.<br /><br />2. Expectations: Rotary shavers do required more passes then foil shavers. I expect that I will have to make more passes than a foil shaver, or a high end rotary shaver. I use a mixture of shaving motions -- circular, sideways and vertical against the grain. This has worked well. I also use a fairly light touch so the shaver heads glide and don't pinch the stubble. While it is recommended by experienced users and Philips Norelco that the user shave exclusively with the shaver for 3-4 weeks to get the skin acclimated, I had no break-in period right from the start. This may be due in part to shaving every day, using a light touch and the variety of shaving motions.<br /><br />3. Quiet, slow speed: I don't have any other shaver to compare this with; however, I go by results. The shaver doesn't have a high revolution sound to it and is fairly quiet; however, the results on my daily stubble growth have been satisfactory. so when people complain about the slow speed and sound of the motor, I take that with a grain of salt. The shaver does get the job done.<br /><br />4: On durability of shaver and cutters: I'll have to wait a year before I determine how long the cutting heads last. I am though, cleaning them daily and lubricating/degreasing them once a week. I am doing a dry clean only without rinsing the heads under water. This does take a few minutes, to carefully remove the cutting heads and the cutters from the combs; however, I don't spend any more time than I would with a normal razor where I pre-wash my face and lather on shaving cream. I expect that how long I can use the cutting heads will be dependent on the thickness of my beard, the design/manufacture of the cutters, and the care I take of the shaver. If I find the cutters getting dull within a year, then I my satisfaction level may change.<br /><br />5. Battery: I'm getting nearly 3 weeks of shaving before I need to charge the shaver. Again, I expect that this will decrease over time through battery wear.<br /><br />Other considerations in my purchase: I'm going to be living overseas. I wanted a shaver that could be used either cordless or with cord. Higher priced wet/dry shavers tend to run on battery only after charging and cannot be used with cord. I was also concerned about cost. Foil shavers seem to have higher blade and foil replacement costs, as do the cleaning system cartridges for high end models. Budget was a consideration. The approximate $25 cost for the replacement HQ8 cutters seems reasonable when compared with replacement costs for other shavers. It's still, though an expense to consider down the road.<br /><br />I realize that uses with extremely heavy beards may or may not find the PT730 acceptable. For me, the PT730 has more than fulfilled my expectations for a low to medium range shaver.<br /><br />Update:<br /><br />It's getting close to one year since my purchase and I want to comment on the status of the cutter blades. It is definitely taking longer to get a close shave, yet I feel no pinching when shaving. I still find it more convenient, even taking a longer time, to not have to wet and lather my face and using an old fashioned razor with the expensive replacement blades, despite this shaver not giving as close a shave as a razor. The results I get, though are still acceptable. The manufacturer's advice to replace the blades yearly may be accurate. A few things to keep in mind, whichmay have affected the blades lasting this long.<br /><br />1) I always do a dry clean after shaving and do not run the shaver under water.<br />2) I use the Norelco cleaning spray once a week.<br />3) I put a few drops of oil on the cutter blades once a week.<br /><br />--------------------------------------------<br />Second Update:<br /><br />It's a little over one year. Longer shaving times -- 5 minutes or so for a light growth of 1-2 days. Yet again, there is no pinching. I haven't replaced the cutter blades, but may in a few months. I would still highly recommend this, one year later.<br /><br />Third Update:<br /><br />It's been over two years and I just changed the cutter blades -- long overdue. Until I did, it took more than five minutes to shave. Under the chin with longer hairs was more difficult. I had to repeatedly go over the same area countless times. Still, though, no nicking. With the new cutter blades, it's like new. Battery is still holding a charge.and do not run the shaver under water. 2) I use the Norelco cleaning spray once a week. 3) I put a few drops of oil on the cutter blades once a week. -------------------------------------------- Second Update: It's a little over one year. Longer shaving times -- 5 minutes or so for a light growth of 1-2 days. Yet again, there is no pinching. I haven't replaced the cutter blades, but may in a few months. I would still highly recommend this, one year later. Third Update: It's been over two years and I just changed the cutter blades -- long overdue. Until I did, it took more than five minutes to shave. Under the chin with longer hairs was more difficult. I had to repeatedly go over the same area countless times. Still, though, no nicking. With the new cutter blades, it's like new. Battery is still holding a charge.

  493. My intent for the purchase of an electric razor is to replace shaving my face and head with a straight razor. This electric razor does a good job shaving my head and a mediocre job face and neck. I attribute this to having different types of hair. I have straight and slightly thick hair on my head and thick and curly facial hair. I find shaving dry I only need to make 3 to 4 pass on my head and 2 to 3 with electric razor liquid. The resulting cut is the same. It almost a smooth shave, but you can feel a little stubble. At the end of the day, my head is pretty much velcro. I imagine if you have really thick hair, you may have problems getting it shaved with this. If I let my hair go for a few days, I have to make numerous passes and I can hear the motor struggling.<br /><br />On my face and neck, I have to make numerous passes and there are always a few hairs that just don't get picked up. Always been the case no matter which electric razors I've used in the past.<br /><br />A few things to note, the head just warm up rather quickly and I find it affects the shaving. As other reviews mention, the motor does seem rather weak. This razor is best for maintaining a clean shave everyday, rather than shaving every other day or so. What works best for me is to keep it by my desk, and whenever I check my work email before heading out to work, I'll shave my head and face. Even if I miss a spot or two, it is not really noticeable and I'll get it when I get home or make a note to make a pass in the morning. Works for me! A full charge lasts me about a week, but I use it significantly longer during shaves.<br /><br />Cleaning is simple. Open the head, tap against the sink, and rinse with water. It comes with a brush for the hair that is just stuck. Easy process.<br /><br />For face shaving, I'd give it a 3/5.<br />For head shaving, I'd give it a 4/5. (As long as you shave daily) I'm taking 1 point off because of the motor being easily strained and not being able to take thickerhair well.<br /><br />Ultimately, if you purchase this to replace razor shaving, you'll be disappointed if you care about shave quality. I stopped caring about having a silky smooth head and this is a happy middle ground for convenience and somewhat smooth. I fully expect to shave with my straight razor every now and then in the future, but in the meantime, this fits my bill and I'm happy with it as I wasn't expecting it to do decently on facial hair.
  494. My job requires I stay clean shaven and this little baby does the job its meant to. The back pop up part doesnt work all that great but I ordered it not even knowing it had one so it was an extra that I didn't need. The main unit however shaves pretty well!
