  503. I was using a Norelco Spectra that I lost the head piece for. Rather than buy the parts to repair it, I went with the 730. Chose the 730 over the 724 because it supposedly has a higher end shaving system and a longer life battery. You can also clean the 730 by rinsing it under a faucet which is a nice convenience.<br /><br />The 730 gives a pretty close shave. It is not nearly as smooth as the old Spectra and the motor does not seem as strong. There are some other features that the Spectra had such as displaying the number of minutes remaining for battery life and settings for different face sensitivity that I miss. The side burn trimmer works well.<br /><br />It is not a bad shaver for the price, but if you can afford it, I would go with a higher end razor.
  504. This razor cuts pretty clean on my cheeks, and chin. However it does not do a good job on the neck. To be fair my neck hair grows in all different directions. The razor is still more effective in close shaves, but for a quick and dirty job this works. The shape also makes it difficult to get under the nose.
  505. I moved from an expensive Braun razor with an even more expensive cleaning system. This razor cleans with a warm water rinse and gives a close, comfortabl shave. It requires an overnight charge every two weeks.
  506. I love this Phillips Norelco PT730 Powertouch Electric Razor because it has 3 blades and it runs with a rechargeable battery. The 3 blades that this electric razor has are washable. They are not very sharp and that's why they don't cut my skin.
  507. Purchased on Amazon. Great shaver, meet expectations. Easy to maintain, rinse under hot water to clean. Recommend this shaver for home and travel. A/C charger 100 -220v and no adapter needed.
  508. This is a very nice device. Much slower motor speed than my previous Norelco (which is about 20 years old), but works much better, especially when I go a few days between shaves.

  516. JUNK, CRAP, GARBAGE, WASTE. This piece of crap has a weak motor and weak batteries. It runs very slowly and takes much longer than other Norelco shaver I've owned. It takes so long that the cutting heads become rather warm, indicating that a lot of energy is going into friction rather than into cutting hair. I have an old Remington DA307 with a hole in the foil that works much better than this crappy chink made JUNK.
  517. In spite of stellar reviews, this razor did not hold up. It is now in pieces in a drawer and seems unfixable.
  518. I used a Norelco twice in the past. They used to be a hassle to clean, and didn't shave well unless you also used a beard setup lotion.<br /><br />The PT730 cleans up completely in a few seconds under hot water and gives a much better shave than the old electrics, without having to use a setup lotion.<br /><br />I'm also impressed with the recharge indicator, a light that stays off until you need a charge. It went on after about two weeks of daily use, so I recharged. After about 8 hours the light went off. This may sound trivial, but too many rechargeable products give highly ambiguous signals about when a battery needs a recharge and when it is finally charged. Norelco has found the single simplest solution.<br /><br />This is a terrific product. The most hassle-free shave I've had in nearly 50 years of shaving.

  541. I bouught the PT730 for myself for Christmas. Having bought it in November, I had a chance to read the reviews before I bought it, and while waiting to open my \\"present\\". After only two days of use, and I know that it's early to have a complete opinion, I must say that I like this new razor. First off, it's replacing a 10 year old razor, so I think I was due getting a new one. The first thing I noticed was how much quieter the PT730 was than my old electric-only razor. I can actually hear the blades cutting my beard. Several of the comments mentioned that the PT730 was \\"slower\\" than they preferred. So far, I'm OK with it's speed. Of course, it's brand new with brand new blades, so I'll have to hold judgement on its speed to see if there's a problem later on down the line as the blades start to lose their edge. For the price, I'm happy - so far.

  584. I bought several for my friends in China.<br /><br />However, it turns out that chargers do not work at all. Not like many people might think, it's not because that 220V standard voltage in China(compared to 110V in USA). Actually, the problem is that charger and shaver itself doesn't match: shaver demands input voltage as 15V but charger provides only 8V. That means they cannot even be charged in the states! After I replace it with a charger with the correct output voltage, it works.<br /><br />What's even worse is the fact that I bought them(9) in 4 times around November. More people might be affected due to this problem. I'm so upset about this.

  646. I got this as my third Norelco to replace the last one. It's pretty good.<br /><br />Pros:<br /> - the battery lasts forever. I charged it once I can't remember how many days ago and it just keeps working.<br /> - it will run on a chord (my old one had the batteries die. I replaced them myself with a soldering iron, but they didn't last long either - then I used the chord only for many years).<br /> - it shaves pretty good<br /><br />Cons:<br /> - I also shave with a 5-blade razor (when I shave my head), and sorry, this just isn't as close. But it's at least as close as my old one. If you hold your skin tight with one hand and do circles with this razor, it's pretty good.<br /> - the combination of holes and slots is a bit gimicky to me. My old one had just slots and I think it was a little better at shaving after going about two days. If I have long stubble, it takes some effort to get them.<br /> - when I use it on my lower neck, I get irritation. That's probably the same as my old one, but technology hasn't made that any better. If you shave areas like that more often, I think they build up a tolerance.<br /><br />The trimmer is acceptable - works but nothing real exciting (a little awkward for my ears...)

  653. I have used this razor for about 3 weeks now and it has worked great for me. I actually bought one for my father first and I was impressed enough to buy a 2nd one for me.<br /><br />I have an average or better beard and I have always used electric razors. In the past, I tended to buy the low-end Norelco for about $25-30 and just replace them instead of buying new blades. They worked OK for a while but the battery life was never very good.<br /><br />I have shaved about 12 times and I am still on the 1st charge with this razor. It is working well for me even if I wait 3 or 4 days between shaves. It is much quieter than my previous razors and I like the reduced charge time (8 vs 16 hours).<br /><br />For about $50, this is a good deal. I was looking at about $25 to replace the blades in my old razor. It is a big step up from the low-end versions I used in the past and worth the extra $25 for me.<br /><br />Pro's<br /><br />Quiet<br />Can skip a few days between shaves without problems<br />Holding a charge well<br /><br />Con's<br /><br />None so far<br /><br />Update 5/3/2014<br /><br />I have been using this razor for over 5 weeks now (3 to 4 times per week) and I am still on the first charge.<br /><br />Update 7/31/2014<br /><br />I still like this razor. I finally had to recharge it at the end of May 2014. The initial charge lasted about 9 weeks when used 3 times a week, so about 27 quick shaves ( < 3 minute per shave).

The assembly will plug back into the body without issue, but this would have been nice to know. Other than that, this has been a pretty good unit. It shaves a lot better than my old one and will recharge in less than an hour. Easier to clean being able to pass it under running water.<br /><br />UPDATE(12/23/2013) Shaver is advertised to work using the cord or cordless. Cordless works fine. If I try to use the cord, it keeps falling out as it does not fit snugly into the plug.

With the Norelco it just glides over my skin and I can barely feel it, but it gives me a shave just as good as a razor. I don't know if I'm ever going to use a razor again as using this shaver is so much easier and faster.<br /><br />After you finish shaving all you have to do is open the top and rinse it with water, close the top and shake off the excess water, then reopen the top and let it air dry.

  767. I have used shave razor and shave cream for more than 15 years plus. I have tried different electric razors; shave once with it, my face chopped up and beard still standing. I would either throw it away or give it away and gave up on electric razor.<br />I believe I then got an e-mail from Amazon or I came across the Philips Norelco PT730 @ the Amazon site.<br />I studied the electric razor, read info presented, and went to Norelco site to check this razor out.<br />The price was awesome and I would receive it timely- I placed the order and received my razor within 48 hours.<br />Once I unpacked the razor I got it started on charging.<br />WOW after all these years I finally found an electric razor that provides a smooth shave without chopping my face up.<br />This razor delivers everything they state it will; it has to be the triple head.<br />I put the razor to the test shaving a three day growth. The razor provided a smooth shave. Cleaning the razor is a breeze- push a button, head pops up, and rinse out under running water.<br />Anyone that wants a smooth shave-this is your electric razor. If you need to buy a gift - you will not go wrong with this choice.<br />I have a minor concern; replacement heads are not sold at Amazon the last I checked. As I stated a minor concern that will not be an issue until next year.
  768. This shaver was above expectations. I was going to order new shaving heads for my old Norelco but for a little bit more I could replace the complete shaver. The PT730 holds a charge longer and gives a shave almost as close as a razor. I was a bit apprehensive when I first turned it on because it seemed to run slower than the old one and I was afraid the shave would suffer. This to my surprise was not the case. I would highly recommend this shaver.
  769. It cuts great, but it holds water in it for a long time after you wash it and it runs out the end where the electric plug is. Should have had a water proof section at the end.
  770. My husband loves his new Norelco.
  771. I have always used Norelco and this one works fine
  772. I made my husband a happy man.
  773. Arrived quickly. I really like the PT730 shaver after using it for about a week now. I used a Schick Quatro for years. When the handle finally broke I decided to look at electric shavers and chose this one after reading all the (mostly) positive reviews. It does a fairly close shave once you get used to the different type of razor. It is quieter than I expected which is good since I am up before everyone else in the house. Overall I am pleased with this razor and would recommend it!
  774. Great battery and shaves well
  775. Works like a champ. Husband is very pleased with all aspects, especially that one can use it while it is charging.
  776. Works great on my 18 yr old sons beard.
  777. It's a pretty good electric razor, especially when considering the price. It's quite compact, light, and quiet, but doesn't necessarily give the closest shave. The machine is washable, so that makes the cleanup fairly simple and convenient. The 8 hour charge time can be a hindrance at times, but your charging sessions will be far between each other unless you shave daily. Overall, I'd certainly recommend if you're looking for a quite, reasonably cheap electric razor.
  778. just what i was looking for! excellent!
  779. Ask me again when the warranty expires. Too soon to tell.
  780. Good, Perfect, but sometimes not clean shave
  781. I like the razor and I like the way I can wash it with hot water under the faucet. It does a nice close shave, is easy to clean, the trimmer is nice, and it holds a charge well.<br /><br />To me the motor sounds as if it is running at low revolutions, but it does the job.
  782. Did a pretty good job on my husband heavy beard.
  783. Great razor, works well, long time between recharges, well made. On/Off switch does not look too durable but has given no problems so far.
  784. Fast shipping. Average electric razor. Takes MANY passes to get the hairs on the neck under your jaw. HOWEVER, this thing has held a charge for many days and it is very quiet. If you shave daily it may work better. Anything more than two days growth and this razor HURTS when it shaves. Tried it after 3 days growth and about went through the roof with pain from pulled hairs.
  785.   791. I usually use razor blades to shave, but for those times wehen you don't have a lot of time, this rechargable razor gives a nice close shave in a very short time and at a price t5hat doesn't break your wallet.
  792. it works great, just what i was looking for on my face.love the trimmer and how easy it is to clean
  793. loving the electric razor and i am never ever going back to handle razor again! IT shave close and smoothly update!! the thing broke on me very fast, less than a year and only one of the shaver side was working
  794. light and feel comfortable.
  795. I was replacing my Remington R7130 with this Philips Norelco PT730 Powertouch Electric Razor after having read several site reviews comparing it to much higher priced rotary and foil razors. My Remington is MUCH better, but the trimmer died so I thought I was moving up in the razor area and would have a functioning trimmer. This Philips weighs less, feels more plasticy and does not cut as close even with more applied pressure. It just feels cheap. For $60 an electric razor should get the job done, and this one barely performs.
  796. I have a light beard, so got a clean shave from day one. The rotary principle is the only way to go because no matter which way the hair is leaning, the rotary cutters will get em, and the floating cutter heads will adapt to the contours of the skin. Much, much more efficient than the fixed bar shaving heads.
  797. I travel a lot and this works in every place I've been (US, Brazil, Thailand, etc). It's a quality product and hard to beat for the price.

Also like being able to clean head and shave with water and soap. Good design and price was reasonable in comparison to the last Norelco bought at the local &#34;W&#34; world.   806. Husband loved this razor, got the newest one this year, had the older version for quite a few years.

  809. The PT730 is a nice, effective razor, BUT, it's $10 more and basically the same as the PT720 model, which my husband has also tried. The only noticeable different with PT730 is that is has a pop-up trimmer (which he barely uses) and the design is slightly more travel friendly - but not by much...<br /><br />As I mentioned with the PT720 review, the Lithium Ion battery holds the charge well. The box claimed that a full charge lasts up to 14 days - we haven't tested it for that long, but it worked for a week just fine. A 3-minute charge is just enough for one shave - good for anyone in a rush. The shaving head is easy to clean and the cleaning brush is a nice accessory, although not really necessary as you can clean without out. The full 2-year warranty is a nice bonus.<br /><br />So, it's a good razor, I just don't get why they make so many different models which are essentially the same...
  810. Works well. Happy with purchase.
  811. It's been over 10 years since I regularly used an electric razor. I've owned at least 6 electrics of various brands and types (rotary, foil, etc.) over the years, and have always returned to using a blade after 6 months or so. I would always get tired of the skin irritation, the poor, uneven closeness of the shave, and the length of time a reasonably close shave would take. But I figured it's been 10 years since I last tried one, and wet razors have made tremendous advances in closeness and comfort, maybe electrics have gotten better, too.<br /><br />I didn't want to spend a fortune on an electric razor, but I also didn't want the bottom end of the product line, so I went with the Norelco PT730 as it seems to offer some higher-end feature like a rechargeable Lithium-Ion battery, the \\"Super Lift & Cut\\" blade system (which promises to offer a closer shave with less irritation), a built-in trimmer, and a fully washable design (which I was very interested in).<br /><br />Not all that much has changed with electrics in the past 10 years. Same basic shape and \\"floating\\" rotary blade layout as my last Norelco (no idea of the model number). They added some nice looking trim stripes, grippy surfaces, and ergonomic curves to the body, so it's easier to hold onto. And it's A LOT lighter than I remember my old one being. Probably a combination of the Lithium Ion battery and a lot more plastic parts - but that's what you get today no matter what you buy. The \\"controls\\" (on/off, and trimmer) are easy to reach and activate, and have a quality feel like they will last for awhile.<br /><br />I followed the directions and charged up the unit until the charging light lit up continuously (took roughly overnight). The next morning when I went to use it for the first time, I was struck just how quiet the shaver is in operation. I could probably use this in the master bathroom with the door closed and not wake my sleeping girlfriend. I was also worried that it was so quiet that it lacked the necessary power to do the job. Fortunately, I was worried for nothing because it powered through my 2 day beard growth without slowing noticeably. I didn't have very high expectations for a close shave that first day because I needed to get used to using an electric razor again. Like every manufacturer warns in their owners manual, Philips Norelco has the standard disclaimer: \\"Your skin may need 2 or 3 weeks to get accustomed to the Philips shaving system\\". I did however, find the shaver easy to hold and manipulate around the curves of my face. I got a decent shave, though no where near as close as a razor shave. It's always a good idea to freshly wash your face just prior to shaving. This removes the facial oils that clog up a razor, and lifts the whiskers off your face for a closer shave. It's VERY IMPORTANT to thoroughly dry your face first before using the razor as the moisture on your skin will cause the heads to drag making shaving most frustrating. They offer alcohol based pre-shave products that clean and dry your face faster than air alone. These can dry out the skin though.<br /><br />I've been using the shaver roughly every other day now for just about a month. I've gotten very comfortable with directing the razor over the different areas of my face. My beard grows very flat on my neck and requires many many passes in different directions to obtain a close shave. Just like every other electric razor I have owned this inevitably causes burning and irritation in that area after each shave. Shaving this area on my neck is probably the biggest reason I don't usually use an electric.<br /><br />Shaving my cheeks and jaw worked fairly well and I got a close shave in those areas after a few passes - not much irritation at all. I wear a goatee and getting in close around the edge of my facial hair was not easy. The circular blades have a border around them that attaches them to the shaver body. This border makes it somewhat difficult to get in close to the edge of my goatee and resulted in some light stubble remaining around the border of my goatee. The goal with well trimmed facial hair is a very close shave around this border which makes the goatee look very neat and sculpted. To be fair, this sharp, clean border is even difficult with a wet razor and requires practice.<br /><br />After shaving I love that I can just flip up the heads and rinse them off with hot water. Saves a lot of aggravation. I have a small spray bottle of alcohol that I spritz on the heads afterward to speed drying. (You're supposed to let the heads dry before closing them back up.) They state in the manual: \\"For the best cleaning results, we advise you to use the Philips Cleaning spray (HQ110).\\" This stuff is basically alcohol with a bit of mineral oil in a spray can for 6 buck or so. Save your money.<br /><br />I used the trimmer function a few times to \\"pre-shave\\" my beard when it was especially long after 3 or 4 days growth. It did trim my long whiskers somewhat but is under-powered for the job. I ended up using my Norelco beard trimmer to finish the job, as it is designed for this kind of work. The trimmer also does a lack-luster job at trimming the edges of my goatee and sideburns. But to be fair it is just as bad as every other built-in trimmer I've used in the past - so I'm not deducting any points for this.<br /><br />I didn't actually time my shaves but I estimate it takes me 5 to 7 minutes roughly every other day to get a close shave. I guess I got 3 - 4 full power shaves between each 8 hour recharge. I was running out of juice near the end of one shave and I plugged the unit in to finish it. A bit more awkward with the cord but it's nice to know you won't get stuck running out of power in the middle of a shave when you're late for work! You can also do a quick 3 minute charge for 5 minutes of cordless shaving, though I didn't try this.<br /><br />Not surprisingly, I still prefer the closeness and lack of irritation of a high quality 5-blade wet razor. And as usual because I have to spend so long repeatedly going over the same areas of my beard to get a close shave, there is really no time savings (for me) with an electric razor. But as far as electrics go the Philips Norelco PT730 PowerTouch Rechargeable Cordless Razor is a very nice product at a reasonable price point (I spent more for my last Norelco 10 years ago!). I found the ability to just flip-up the shaving heads and rinse them under hot water to be a real time saver, and it kept the razor performing much better between thorough cleanings involving disassembly of the heads.<br /><br />All in all, I can recommend this product as a very good choice in electric razors at a fair price for the features and performance.e remaining around the border of my goatee. The goal with well trimmed facial hair is a very close shave around this border which makes the goatee look very neat and sculpted. To be fair, this sharp, clean border is even difficult with a wet razor and requires practice. After shaving I love that I can just flip up the heads and rinse them off with hot water. Saves a lot of aggravation. I have a small spray bottle of alcohol that I spritz on the heads afterward to speed drying. (You're supposed to let the heads dry before closing them back up.) They state in the manual: \\"For the best cleaning results, we advise you to use the Philips Cleaning spray (HQ110).\\" This stuff is basically alcohol with a bit of mineral oil in a spray can for 6 buck or so. Save your money. I used the trimmer function a few times to \\"pre-shave\\" my beard when it was especially long after 3 or 4 days growth. It did trim my long whiskers somewhat but is under-powered for the job. I ended up using my Norelco beard trimmer to finish the job, as it is designed for this kind of work. The trimmer also does a lack-luster job at trimming the edges of my goatee and sideburns. But to be fair it is just as bad as every other built-in trimmer I've used in the past - so I'm not deducting any points for this. I didn't actually time my shaves but I estimate it takes me 5 to 7 minutes roughly every other day to get a close shave. I guess I got 3 - 4 full power shaves between each 8 hour recharge. I was running out of juice near the end of one shave and I plugged the unit in to finish it. A bit more awkward with the cord but it's nice to know you won't get stuck running out of power in the middle of a shave when you're late for work! You can also do a quick 3 minute charge for 5 minutes of cordless shaving, though I didn't try this. Not surprisingly, I still prefer the closeness and lack of irritation of a high quality 5-blade wet razor. And as usual because I have to spend so long repeatedly going over thesame areas of my beard to get a close shave, there is really no time savings (for me) with an electric razor. But as far as electrics go the Philips Norelco PT730 PowerTouch Rechargeable Cordless Razor is a very nice product at a reasonable price point (I spent more for my last Norelco 10 years ago!). I found the ability to just flip-up the shaving heads and rinse them under hot water to be a real time saver, and it kept the razor performing much better between thorough cleanings involving disassembly of the heads. All in all, I can recommend this product as a very good choice in electric razors at a fair price for the features and performance.
  812. Great razor. Bought it because Norelco stopped making the blades for my old one. Shaves well, rinses out under water (good feature!)   817. This is a high quality shaver, and the best thing is how long the batteries last. I have a small area of facial hair to shave, so a full face would get less shaves, but for me it lasts for months, and the quality is very good. Being able to rinse it under water is an easy way to clean it.
  818. I got this for my hubby but it doesn't work that well and irritates his skin. So dissapointed

  820. never worked at all. had to basically toss it. felt cheap and light. I'm used to my father's heavy old razor made by Philips. I guess Philips has changed A LOT over the years and now they make cheap stuff that doesn't hold up to even normal use. Boo hiss.
  821. Great shave. I wish it had a pop up trimmer.
  822. This product exceeded my expectations. I bought it because I'm on blood thinners from complications following knee replacement surgery and didn't want to risk getting shaving nicks from blade shaving.<br />This product is easy to use, gives a close shave and is very easy to clean. In other words, I love it.<br />If I had known how good these were, I would have bought one years ago.
  823. It get's the job done...eventually. I'm 51 years old and nothing has ever touched my face but a Norelco. I'm not a hairy beast that get's a 5 o'clock shadow every day (no offense to hairy beasts!). This thing takes way more time and effort than my 6863 XL which has served me well for somewhere in the neighborhood of 10 years. It still works as long as you run it on a chord. 10 years and the only thing it could use is some fresh blades. This new PT730 get's a bit closer when all is said and done but it takes more than twice as long.<br /><br />This thing is WEAK. I don't care if a razor is loud so long as it get's the job done. Honestly guys, have you ever been shaving and thought to yourself &#34;Dang! This thing is loud! I wish it wasn't so noisy!&#34;? For someone to praise it for being &#34;quiet&#34; makes little to no sense to me. Who gives a (insert your favorite expletive) how quiet it is? Ever had a complaint from your significant other or your neighbor? &#34;Honey, that is just too loud! Can you go do that in the garage?&#34; I want the hair on my face to disappear and that's all and I don't want to spend 20 minutes doing it.<br /><br />The shave is close once you fight with all of the stragglers and go over every inch of your face...many many times...in front of the mirror. Once it cut's it's close but it just doesn't have any balls. Not a good choice of words but it gets the point across to the subject audience. This thing needs a few more RPM's to make it a real razor that takes about 5 minutes to get the job done, not twenty...
  824. Very good results. Good value for price and for a quick shave! I would recommend this model as excellent value!!!
  825. I've used Norelco rotarys for many years so nothing new.   826. Easy to use, Good shave . Easy cleaning.. I Love it..

  828. Glad I read the reviews and opted for this model over the less pricey model -- definitely worth the difference in price. This one allows me to clean it using hot water from the faucet without having to take it all apart -- a big time saver. Plus, it's quieter than my last one and seems to give a closer shave. So it's a real winner all around.
  829. This was my first electric razor of this type. I only fully shave once a week so this took my skin a lot of time to get used to. It cuts incredibly close on &#34;flat&#34; surfaces like cheeks, however, using it all over the neck proved to be a little more difficult and required a regular razor to finish the job.
  830. The razor is easy to use and lightweight. My husband had surgery on his thumb and it was difficult to shave. Not any more!

  838. Great Price! Did not see any comparable razor in this price range. Very good right out of the box. Using it for three weeks now. I have a moderate beard, am a senior citizen.   841. Be advised: This razor was delivered yesterday. Opened it up, plugged it in, and no green light (which is the sign that it is charging).   842. This is a great razor that provides a classic Norelco Triple Head shave. Ive owned Norelco Triple Head razors for decades and I've never been disappointed. This current model is lighter than previous ones and seems to have superior battery life and shorter charge times. You can also clean it under running water if you wish.<br /><br />Some people complain that Norelco razors burn their skin, but in my experience this is the case with any electric razor until your skin becomes acclimated to it. I don't think the Norelco is any better or worse in this regard. Another complaint is that electric razors don't shave as close as a blade, which may be true. On the other hand, it's easy to throw the Norelco in your brief case and do a quick touch up in your office, or in the back of a cab on your way to the airport. In almost any case and with almost any beard, the results will be superior to a blade you used several hours ago.<br /><br />The only personal complaints I have is that the pop-up trimmer is not very effective and the batteries are not replaceable. I rarely use the trimmer, a dedicated trimmer works way better and on my last Norelco razor the batteries lasted for over 7 years, so I really have no complaints. This is an excellent razor for the money.

It takes a heck of a charge and you'll really get several shaves off a full charge.   864. I bought it because an old Norelco rotary I had was easier on my neck in the summer time, but I preferred my Remmington Foil for the rest of my shave. This new razor was supposed to have better cutting heads and, although it gives a decent shave, it irritates my neck skin worse than the Remmington did. I've used it for a month, so maybe it will get better. Battery charge is good, over two weeks before recharge. Very light and easy to hold. I would recommend it as a good razor for the price.   865. Very quiet , does everything well about 90 % five stars , 90 % is very good these days , cleans empty in 4 seconds , dose not leave any ugly neck hairs uncut ... has sideburns trimmer , cord or cordless , easy recharge , but why bother. STEVE .F.
  866. It's an electric razor. It works, but it's not great. I may have to move off of the Norelco brand when this one stops working. I've used their products for the past 25 years without trying another brand. No matter what I do with these style razors, I always have to spend a ton of time shaving the same spots over and over again. New blades and new techniques haven't helped that. It might just be my manly strong beard hairs or something...I don't know..but I get tired of having to recharge this thing every few days just because it takes forever to get a clean shave.<br /><br />At this price point, I don't expect perfection or exceptional quality, but a shave is a shave is a shave. Turn it on, cut the hairs so the face is relatively smooth, and move on with your day. This does that, but it seems to take more time than it should.<br /><br />3 stars....I'd say that's fair based on my experience.
  867. It works as well as any electric razor that I have used, better than most.

  869. I have used this shaver for over a week and have no complaints. I'm pleased with the shave and comfort. Have a few issues when comparing to my previous Norelco. One thing I am not pleased about is the wall wart power plug. I preferred the power conversion in the razor handle. It is much easier to travel with a small power cord instead of the the converter as a part of the plug on the wall. (The old way also made the shaver feel more substantial.) The speed of the blades seems to be significantly slower. I think this is just something I need to adjust to after having used faster Norelco razors for the past 25 years.

  882. I'm not sure why there are so many negative comments about the new Philips Norelco electric razors. I have been using Norelco for over 30 years and this new one is a very good razor.<br /><br />It was NOT made in China - the packaging says made in Netherlands. It IS much quieter, and I think that causes users to perceive that it is not running as strongly as older units.<br /><br />I replaced my old Norelco because the shaving heads cost more than a new razor. The new one worked very well the first time I used it, since my face did not have to become accustomed to electric razors. I realize the comparison to my old unit is flawed because the shaving heads on my old razor needed replacing, but I have no complaints about the PT730 on my neck, or face.<br /><br />One thing I notice is their warning about not pressing too hard on the skin or you will distort the foils on the heads. I had to think consciously while shaving, and it's actually nice not to have to bear down to get a close shave.<br /><br />It actually cost $10 less to buy this shaver than to replace the heads on my old unit, and I am experiencing results as good as I would have expected with my old shaver if I had opted for replacement heads.<br /><br />Positives - light; quiet; good shave, can use with cord; easy to clean; good pop-up trimmer; much better on-off switch than old (sliding) unit had; Lithium Ion batteries which will not get &#34;memory&#34; like NiCads and refuse to charge.<br /><br />Negatives - no storage cradle (it fits in the old cradle I have); no leather case (it fits into the old leather case); cord is skinny &#34;phone charger type&#34; instead of heavy coiled AC charging cord from old unit; lacks the series of LEDs to indicate state of charge (but there ARE LEDs to show full charge and no charge).
  883. excellent shaver, powerful, easy to use, reasonable price, much better than my old Norelco.

I have to go over the same spot about 10 times for it to cut all the hair off and give me a clean shave. I don't know if this is a common issue with circular blades, as I was using a foil shaver before?? Not sure. The pop up trimmer is also just okay, I have to dig into my skin for it to cut and trim my sideburns. Battery life is excellent, the charge time is excellent, and the colored battery indicators are nice as well. It is easy to clean, easy to change the blades as well. It's light weight, ergonomic and comfortable to hold (as you'll be holding it a while). Besides the time it takes to shave and how many passes I have to take to actually cut the hair, the unit is nice. Although when it's time to replace this, I think I may go back to a foil electric razor. Hope this review helps you to make an informed decision!

  961. I have used Norelco razors for 30 years or more, and each one seems to be a little better. This one does a very good job, and holds a charge for a reasonable length of time. It also seems to recharge fairly quickly.<br /><br />The only (minor) complaint that I have is that it just quits cold when the charge gets low. With my older Norelco razors, I can hear the motor begin to slow when the battery charge is getting low. Since I usually shave in the car while driving to work, it can be quite handy to have some advance warning before the razor dies.<br /><br />The product description says that an LED indicator panel lets you know when it's time to recharge, but I haven't seen that so far. It may be that I'm missing something, and I will be sure to check for this more often. Of course I won't normally SEE the signal while I'm using the razor, unless I happen to be shaving my forehead. (I don't)<br /><br />All things considered, I have no regrets about purchasing this razor. I'm not giving it the full 5 stars, but I would not hesitate to recommend it to a friend.

  970. I keep an electric razor for one reason: being late and being able to shave in the car. I don't remember the previous Norelco model I had (which, after several years of dependable use, could no longer hold a charge), but it was a lower-end model, I'm sure. This PT730 is very inferior to that model.<br /><br />First, as other reviewers have pointed out, the motor is much weaker than previous Norelcos. This, as I found out the hard way, is actually quite important if you have a few days growth of beard to shave. I was late for a doctor's appointment, had 2-to-3 days growth of beard, and spent 15 minutes TRYING to get this brand new, fully-charged shaver to do its job. The upper face took quite a while. The neck/under-chin area was - believe it or not - nearly impossible to shave and I gave up after a long while, fearing a bright red neck from irritation (I don't have an explanation as to why it couldn't cut the neck hairs).<br /><br />My previous Norelco always did the job. This Norelco is quite inferior. Even though I paid only $27 via Amazon discounts/coupon, I am very disappointed in this item.<br /><br />UPDATE 1/10/2013: After using this on one day's beard growth - as most people would use this I suppose - I can understand why others have given this high ratings. It does do a good job, though it takes longer than a higher-powered razor would. However, I'm sticking with the 2 stars: if you decide not to shave over the weekend, do NOT expect this thing to handle 3 days of beard growth on Monday morning, it simply cannot handle it.
  971. Newly redesigned shaver series offers advantages previous models lacked making this PT series 22nd century.<br />Price was most more than advantages.

  973. I always had Norelco shavers and they all worked well including this one. I recommend this at this value price.
  974. Never been a big fan of cordless razors, but I've always kept one around for quick touch-ups and when I'm running late. The main feature of this [[ASIN:B006GQYSGO Philips Norelco PT730 Powertouch Electric Razor]] is that (stop me if you've heard this before) it has two cutting edges. The first blade cuts longer hairs and pulls whiskers off the surface of the skin, then the second blade comes along and cuts the shorter ones even closer.<br /><br />I don't which to credit - the new-ness of this shaver compared to the 4-year-old I left, or the cutting-edge double-blade technology they're so proud of, but these first dozen or so shaves have been very smooth and close, with virtually none of the burn electrics tend to leave. The rotary head that give and take independently definitely help.<br /><br />The overall design is pretty sleek, the LED battery level indicator is easy to read, and a full charge gives you 40 minutes of run time which seems like a lot. This shaver beat my expectations, better in every way than any electric I've owned before. I'm not quite ready to go electric full-time - there's $60 of Gillette razor blades I'd have to use up first - but at least this razor leaves me thinking it's possible now.
  975. I've been using a Braun single-foil shaver for about six years, and when the trimmer attachment broke on that, I decided to try something different. The description for this product hyped the close shave and movable heads and the reviews looked good, so I gave it a shot.<br /><br />When the product came my first impression is that it felt lightweight and sounded like a toy. I've now been using it for six months and I'm convinced of its durability, and the quieter motor is a nice benefit compared to the Braun. The ergonomic-looking shape is actually awkward to hold, but that's not a big deal. It's easier to clean than the Braun since the whole head unit flips open and closed quickly. The battery life is also an improvement.<br /><br />Regarding the shaving performance, I can report that it is exactly identical to my old shaver. I gave my face a month to adapt to the new cutter, then did a few experiments where I shaved one side of my face with the old shaver and the other with the new shaver. Immediately after the shave, or that evening, or the next day, I could see or feel no difference whatsoever. All the hype in the product description is just that -- hype.<br /><br />I had hoped to get a closer or quicker shave with a new product; instead I got the same shave with a couple minor upgrades. Nothing to complain about, but a bit disappointing.

Yesterday the low power light came on for the first time and I had to charge it. That is five months of daily use on one charge!   1053. After much deliberation, I decided to try this Phillips Norelco PT730 Razor, if only for the reason that it could be used while plugged in. Previously I'd had an inexpensive foil razor from Panasonic that I liked very much, but the foil broke and the replacement costs were more than the razor itself.<br /><br />I bought the PT730 to shave my scalp. I typically shave my head with a regular blade razor, and I've tried any number of disposables and cartridge razors. Unfortunately, the amount of time it takes to shave my head due to the many curves and corners makes me take a few days off between shaves, which makes it much harder to shave, especially when the hairs clog the razor, or the blade dulls halfway through shaving my head. The end result is that on more than one occasion I've taken huge chunks of my scalp out with one of these fifty-seven blade monstrosities that Schick and Gillette put out. You've never known pain until you put a styptic pencil on a gaping wound in your head.<br /><br />So bring on the Norelco PT730. First impressions were a bit shaky. The razor feels light, and when turned on, it's quiet and sounds like it's powered by a wind-up engine. But then I plopped it on my head and started shaving. In less time than it takes to shave with a three or four bladed razor, I was able to shave two or three days of growth on my scalp down almost as smooth as a regular razor. I used it on my face, and there were some small razor burns and pulls, but nothing like a previous rotary razor I had a few years back. The flexible heads do a great job of fitting the contours of the face. Clean up was easy, just a rinse, a shake, and some time to dry.<br /><br />Some have argued the razor feels cheap, and it does appear that the accessories, namely the plug and the protective cover for the blades, are cheaper. The power cord is a thin cord that looks to be made out of the same wire as a USB cable. But I was glad to see that Norelco didn't coil the cord. This allows you to use it plugged in at a much further distance from the wall.<br /><br />I cannot yet speak to charge times or usage time but it seems as though the stated 8 hours charge and 40 minute usage are about right.<br /><br />If you're a bald guy who needs a steady solution to shaving your head, I highly recommend the Norelco PT730.This allows you to use it plugged in at a much further distance from the wall.<br /><br />I cannot yet speak to charge times or usage time but it seems as though the stated 8 hours charge and 40 minute usage are about right.<br /><br />If you're a bald guy who needs a steady solution to shaving your head, I highly recommend the Norelco PT730.
  1054. Very close shave plus extremely easy to clean, I wish I would have bought many years ago. If you like to shave your head, this electric razor will give you a very close shave in about 5 - 10 minutes without the mess or irritation. Highly recommended...
  1055. This review compares the Philips Norelco PT730 shaver to the Braun Series 1-190 shaver. I suspect that my comments will apply generally to most vibrating-blade shavers (e.g., Braun) and rotating-blade shavers (e.g., Norelco).<br /><br />I've owned three of the Braun shavers (essentially identical) over the past six years. It would be very difficult to find a more ergonomic electric shaver. They charge quickly and hold charge a long time. About six months ago, I bought the Norelco shaver. It is not nearly as ergonomic as the Braun and does not charge nearly as fast and probably does not hold a charge as long. But the rotating-blade Norelco shaver is quiet and vibration-free, and its shave is a little closer. The Braun works best when the whiskers are short (best if the growth is no older than two days). The Norelco is better on the longer whiskers. I vacillate between the two shavers depending on my mood, whisker length, and perhaps other subconscious factors. I usually use both shavers to complete one shave. The Braun is best for straight edges like sideburns. My recommendation would be to buy both of these shavers.<br /><br />Even though the Braun is more ergonomic, I find as time goes by that I'm using the Norelco shaver more often than the Braun. The Braun shaver has one serious deficiency: The pop-up trimmer on all three of my Braun shavers quit working after a while (I can't remember how long they worked). Not having this trimmer at hand is inconvenient, but I can use the pop-up trimmer on the Norelco.
  1056. I was very impressed by the price. It was much lower than other comparable shavers I researched and the quality of the shave it provides is excellent.
  1057. I bought this in April 2012. It replaced another Norelco shaver which I had for probably close to ten years. The only reason I replaced the old one was because the batteries in the old one finally gave out and it was not cost effective to have them professionally replaced.<br /><br />The new one has a light on it which switches from green to amber when the batteries are getting low. I liked this feature. Also, the new one has lithium batteries which last longer between shaves and are supposed to last longer before needing replacement.<br /><br />Unfortunately, the shaver was completely dead this morning. Since the batteries were not low when I used it yesterday, I suspected the worse. Just to be safe, I plugged it in to charge the batteries. It has been charging for the last six hours. The light is flashing green to indicate it is charging but when I unplug it, it still does not turn on. The shaver has a two year warranty so I will probably get a new one but I will still be out the cost of shipping it someplace and my time.
  1058. I thought the lift and cut was a stretch until I tried it and I was amazed at how much better this razor cut over my old one. I get a good shave every time and am very pleased.

  1069. I have used Norelco shavers since the early 1950s starting with a single rotary head when I was in college. They have all been satisfactory but by far the best is a plug-in Noreloc Rotatract Razor that I have had for at least 30 years. It rivals a straight razor for smoothness. I replaced it with one of the early cordless models. It is my back-up and I don't think I have ever changed the heads. This PT730 is my 2nd favorite so far. It replaces a Norelco shaver that I used for many years and replaced the batteries at least twice at Batteries Plus. I gave up on it when the new heads I bought at WalMart proved about as effective as a rough washcloth.
  1070. It's perfect if you want it to leave 70% of the hair and you want to spend 5 times longer shaving than with a razor.<br />The side burn trimmer actually does a better job than the shaver itself, it's a pathetic product. Do not buy.

  1072. I had been using a Norelco 8150XL for about 7-8 years and had become frustrated by the way it would irritate my neck. This electric razor is much more gentle on my skin as the shaving heads pivot better. The battery takes longer to charge than my old razor (approx 8 hrs vs. 1 hr), but this really isn't a big deal to me. Overall, this is a good value in my opinion and well worth the cost to upgrade.

  1081. I selected this unit over some of the other Norelco because I can shave while charging. This unit charges slower than my old unit but that is not an issue for me. I charge it overnight and it is done by morning. This is a nice light unit, much lighter than my older Norelco. I do like the rinse head capibility - it is so easy to clean when I can rinse in warm water after using. My old unit required taking the heads all apart to get a good cleaning.<br />The trimmer is not good. It works but is way underpowered. I use another unit for beard trimming so it is not a huge issue for me. This would be a 5 star review except for the trimmer.<br />All in all, for me, with a light beard, this is a great shaver. Does what it should in very good order. This entire unit was cheaper that a new blade head for my original - go figure.

  1099. I gave it to my son to review. He's had it for a little over a month, and this is what he had to say:<br /><br />*Easy to clean with removable parts that can be easily reassembled.<br />*Good, clean shave.<br />*Battery life is slightly below average but not so much that it should discourage someone from purchasing.<br />*Louder compared to my previous electric razors.<br />*Corded charger makes it possible to shave while charging.<br /><br />He had a Norelco last time, and it lasted over two years until he accidentally dropped it in the toilet. These are typically reliable and long-lasting products.<br />My husband also uses electric Norelco razors, and his oldest one was 7-8 years old before the battery finally died out. He prefers higher end razors with lift and cut. This does not have lift and cut, but it does a good overall job.<br /><br />Based on my son's positive opinion, I would definitely recommend this product.
  1100. I was given the opportunity through Amazon Vine to review two of Norelco's mid-range electric shavers - the PT720 and the PT730. At first glance, they seem to be identical except for color and the pop-up trimmer on this one (PT730) and the $10 price difference at this writing. However, upon use I find that there is indeed a difference in the way they shave.<br /><br />Both shavers allow you to use them corded or cordless and both shavers can be rinsed clean under water. (You could actually use these razors in the shower, but rotary shavers perform better on a dry beard.) Both shavers feature the same, replaceable, flexing heads - which are amazing in their ability to follow the curves of your face while giving you a close shave. Both shavers last about 40 minutes on a single charge and both have an indicator light for battery status.<br /><br />The differences are that this shaver features Super Lift & Cut (which picks up longer hairs and shaves them smoothly), DualPrecision (which lets you shave even the shortest stubble cleanly), and a pop-up trimmer. The PT720 features Comfort Cut, which gives a gentler shave.<br /><br />In trying both on my husband and sons, I found that for my husband, who has a heavy beard, this shaver gave him a closer shave than the PT720 on his 5 o'clock shadow. For one son, who is in college and shaves infrequently, this shaver picked up the long, scraggly hairs much, much better than the PT720. However, for another son with a heavy beard but very sensitive skin, the PT720 was much more comfortable and he said he would ONLY use that one. I was shocked to see such a big difference because the two shavers really do look identical.<br /><br />The pop-up trimmer works great and I like that it is long enough to use without catching your head hair in the razor head.<br /><br />Clean up is just one press of a button and the head pops open. Then you can rinse the whole thing under the tap! Very easy and convenient. Norelco recommends replacing the head every 12 months for optimum performance. Also included is a little cleaning brush and a plastic head cover to protect the heads between uses.<br /><br />If you are looking for a mid-priced, electric rotary-style shaver without a lot of whistles and bells, I think you will be pleased with this shaver. If you have extremely sensitive skin, you might want to look at Norelco's PT720.head every 12 months for optimum performance. Also included is a little cleaning brush and a plastic head cover to protect the heads between uses.<br /><br />If you are looking for a mid-priced, electric rotary-style shaver without a lot of whistles and bells, I think you will be pleased with this shaver. If you have extremely sensitive skin, you might want to look at Norelco's PT720.
  1101. My husband usually prefers to shave with his razor and the Art of Shaving products. Sometimes he doesn't have time, and I picked this up to speed up his morning routine. He had an electric razor previously, but thought it didn't do a great job. He loves this one, says it gives him a close shave, and he appreciates that it is much quieter than others he has used. He also likes washing it off under the running water. Happy with it.
  1102. This razor has far exceeded all of my expectations!! I couldn’t ask for a better razor. A close shave everytime and easy to clean!
  1103. I've owned half a dozen Norelco shavers in the last 20 years. I would still be using the first one, but I no longer live near the place where they will replace the rechargeable battery for about $10, so I've had to buy new ones primarily because of dead batteries. When I started looking this time, I was shocked to see that Norelco has one shaver that it sells for $350! This one, at one-seventh the cost, is probably still overpriced. It has a less powerful motor than my last Norelco, and in order to make it easier for Norelco to sell this razor in every country, this model now includes a brick plug instead of a standard two-prong North American plug, which simply creates more travel bulk. I also am not fond of the way the head flips off so easily because it doesn't have as secure a locking system as older models. So, while the razor performs adequately, it's not a must-have item. There are better values.
  1104. I have been using Norelco electric shavers since 1960. This one works great and I sure like the under the tap washing feature. The lithium battery seems to give it more power and a longer lasting charge.
  1105. 12/2013 - I bought this as a replacement for a similar P-N rather than replacing its blades.After about a month of use, it seems very similar to the unit it replaced, so my review will be the same. Note that this unit cost more BUT the old one (Philips Norelco 7310 Men's Shaving System ) now shows on Amazon as a different model number(Philips Consumer Lifestyle 7310XL/17 Men's Cord/Cordless Electric Shaver) at a much higher price than I paid then or this model. I'm sure there is an explanation for this ... maybe it is an &#34;improved model&#34; now(?) but it is more than I want to spend. So here is the essence of my previous review which applies to this new unit, with an added update/comment at the end.<br /><br />I have used electric shavers for many years. I looked for a reasonably priced, competent shaver. This is one.<br /><br />It shaves and trims well. It holds a charge long enough to be useful. It runs fine when plugged in, the plug is even small and light. I have only used it a few months so can't comment on long term battery or other durability. It is easily cleaned, allowing use of water. It light weight with nice balance and feel when in use. Simple to use, there are no cutting height or other adjustments but, because it is a basic shaver, others may be do some jobs better such as: extremely long/tough beards; special skin; or shaving exceptionally close. I don't need any of these so it is no problem.<br /><br />It is not fancy or loaded with 'stuff'. It just does its job. All in all a good value.<br /><br />12/2013 - I glanced at a couple other reviews of similar P-N shavers and see others seem to agree with me. It looks like P-N uses the old 'Gillette business model' ...now also used in the printer business and probably plenty others...which is to sell the initial product at a low price and make the big money on replacement parts. Not that there is anything wrong with that...but in the printer case, one can purchase replacement ink/toner from different suppliers, rather than only the original manufacturer...so the Gillette model may be better for electric shavers than printers :-) ... but I depress.<br /><br />I see others, as I, recommend throwing the old unit away or keeping it as a backup for a while then throwing it away...and replacing it rather than buying replacement parts. This is essentially what I did, but paid more for a similar/nearly identical new shaver. I managed to stretch its life to about 4 years at the expense of some rough shaves, good value for the $29.95 I spent in 2009. YMMV...
  1106. As a lifelong Norelco electric razor user, my husband says that the Norelco PT730 Rechargeable Cordless/Cord Tripleheader Razor is one of the best he has ever used. Some may say that an electric razor does not shave as close as shaving with a manual blade razor and shaving cream. Some may enjoy the ritual that goes along with manual shaving. I think most men are mistaken. The Norelco PT730 gives an incredibly close and comfortable shave, easily matching the results of a wet razor shave. (As a wife, I can feel it, too!) He hated the mess of shaving cream and gel, constantly replacing dull razors and walking out of the bathroom with tiny bits of tissue covering a cut or two. (Not sexy!) Even the best manual shavers will cut skin occasionally.<br /><br />The first thing that impressed me about this razor is the sleek, ergonomic design. It feels good in your hand. It was also charged out of the box, which was unexpected. My husband tried it immediately, and said the shave rivaled his blade experiences--very close, very smooth. The pivoting/floating blade heads create an even and stubble-free shave, and the trimmer makes trimming the sideburns and moustache a breeze. Just run the razor under water to clean. It does not get easier than this!<br /><br />I have seen the evolution of electric razors over the decades and cannot believe the progress that has been made. At one time, electric razors could not compete with the close shave a wet manual razor gave, but times have changed. The Norelco PT730 Rechargeable Cordless/Cord Tripleheader Razor is more than a convenience. There's no mess, no fuss, no blades to replace, and no cuts (or necessary tissue). Both your mirror and your mate will love you for it.

I am pleasantly surprised at the closeness of the shave. It is much quieter than my foil razors which was another pleasant surprise. If I don't shave for a few days (like over a long weekend), this razor handles it well whereas with the foil razors I found I had to switch to a blade razor to handle the extra stubble. So that was a third pleasant surprise.
  1169. This is a great shaver. It is a very close shave and is very easy to maintain and use. I wouldn't let your hair get too long (maybe a week or so) because it can hurt in some places as you shave (I have pretty coarse facial hair though, and a lot). It is also very easy to clean.<br /><br />Overall I would recommend this product to anyone as I use it all the time and have no issues with it at all.
  1170. Did this really shave my face? It went so fast and was so quiet that I almost thought that maybe the battery was drained. My previous Norelco shaver of 20 years sounded like a cranky old gas powered buzz saw that required several passes to get the job done. The whine and din nearly made me deaf. The new shaver purrs in comparison.<br /><br />This was a very close shave and almost feels like I did it with a razor in places.<br /><br />WATCH OUT for the PT720. Costs the same often and does not have the sideburn trimmer. There's a $249 shaver out there and how ridiculous and shameful is that for something that goes \\"bzzzzzzzz\\" and removes stuble?

  1204. UPDATE after 1.2 yrs of use: heads completely worn out. Won't cut at all. Motor still good, but entire head assembly must be replaced. PS - head &#34;eats&#34; and holds cotton fuzz/strands (from a towel), which may be stuck in your wiskers. Sounds like a joke, but it's not. They &#34;clog&#34; up the entire cutter head, making it almost non-functioning. A problem I never expected.<br /><br />PRIOR REVIEW: Best $50 razor I've bought in years. Cuts almost as close as a Braun, and plenty close enough for everyday use. Never knicks me. And it holds a charge like crazy. My beard is average, and I can cut every morning for 5 - 7 days on one charge. Overall, very satisfied with the product. Perfect balance of performance, and ease of use. I used to be a huge Braun fan, but I'm now sold on this particular Norelco.<br />PS - motor is Not overpowered. Almost underpowered, but in fact it has just enough power to get through an average beard with no problems at all. So far (4 weeks of use) I'd say it's the perfect amount of power for normal, everyday use. If you have barbed wire for a beard, then Maybe you'd want to look for a stronger motor. All &#34;normal beard&#34; guys, this will work fine for you. I recommend this product.

  1270. I read a few reviews of this product before I bought it, and I agree with others who noted that the motor is slower than earlier Norelco models. Nonetheless, it shaves closer and quicker than the Norelco it replaces (a 15 year old XL-model).<br /><br />Which brings me to my \\"green\\" comment. The only reason I replaced the old XL is the battery wore out, and you cannot just replace the old rechargeable battery with a new one. Norelco continues to build shavers with rechargeable batteries that are soldered into place, so that you can either send the shaver in for them to repair ($30 estimated) or if you dare, try to follow one of the many YouTube demonstrations of unsoldering and replacing a failed battery. I considered doing this with my old shaver, but by the time I had bought an appropriate soldering iron and a replacement battery I would have as much into it as buying a new shaver.<br /><br />The new shaver also has a soldered battery. This is a classic example of planned obsolescence and is unconscionable in this second decade of the 21st century. This is my main reason for the 3-star rating for a product that works like a 4-5 star . . . Boo-hiss, Norelco!!!
  1271. A very inexpensive, well outfitted rechargable razor. Feel a little cheap when holding it compared to my last one (not as solid), but works great!

  1287. I really want to like this trimmer more. It fits in the hand well. It charges quickly. It just looks cool.<br /><br />However, the trimmer does a poor job of shaving the hard to reach areas (mainly around the neck and jaw line) requiring many passes. Eventually this becomes rather irritating on the skin. However, I haven't gotten any bumps because of this. In terms of closeness, you need to wet the razor head before you can get anything close to a decent shave. Lastly, the trimmer feature isn't really useful. You can't get it close to the skin, and it tends to bend and buckle because of how it's hinged.<br /><br />Okay, the negative out of the way, this razor IS easy to clean, the shave quality is decent if you routinely shave every day, and the battery lasts a long time. It's a great razor to travel with.

  1292. All the Norelco dry shavers \\"work\\" the same these days. The old days of 5 lights or LCD screens or different colors and symbols are gone. They now almost all use rechargeable batteries that don't have the same useful life or power as the good old Ni-Cads I used to see last 10+ years (they now use either Li-Ion or NiMH, the NiMH seem to work better for me). The 6943 and other variations of cord only HQ56 shavers are gone, as are the 8100 and other HQ8/9 cord only models, or they are at ridiculous prices.<br /><br />One version swivels, one version works wet and there are a few old left overs that basically do the same thing, but their batteries are aging as they have not been made for years. So, unless you want to swivel or shave wet, it boils down to the difference between the current heads and here I am speaking of the HQ56 or the HQ8 or HQ9. I have never used the RQ series and I never will. I just don't see the logic or buying an entire new head when you only need new blades, and $50 for blades each year is more than the entire price of the PT730. So here it is, after shaving with Norelco for 45+ years with all the different heads.<br /><br />The HQ56 are OK. After you use them for a while, it takes a bit longer to get the thicker stubble and you have to go back over the same spot a little more. They don't seem to last a full year, but when they are new they do a decent job. When they are cheap, and I mean $10 or so less than the HQ8/9 then they are a good deal and you won't mind when the shaver batteries die in 3-4 years because the shaver was cheap as well.<br /><br />However, if you use the HQ56 for a while and then go to the HQ8/9 you will think a barber moved into your bathroom and just gave you a custom shave. Not only that, you will find that it takes quite a bit less time, almost half. I have yet to feel a significant difference between the HQ8 and HQ9, probably because they do different things better. The HQ8 has fewer cutters and a few largerholes for longer hairs and the HQ9 has more holes and a system of concentric cutters for a faster shave. Cutter count is not the only thing that makes a difference though. The old fashioned HQ56 has nearly twice the cutters of the HQ8 and the HQ8 does a better job. I mix them (HQ8 and 9)on a single shaver as I have yet to decide which I like best.<br /><br />So, in the HQ8/9 heads, the PT730 is the best deal. Also, rather important, the 730 keeps the blade speed up when it is on batteries. When Norelco switched to the newer batteries and dumped the Ni-cads (EU regulations) the early models had a big problem keeping the speed up after a few minutes of shaving. If you wanted the fastest blade rotation, you had to use a cord. A 50 minute battery life is pretty worthless when the shave stinks after 10 minutes because the blades are too slow. This latest version seems to have fixed this issue pretty well.<br /><br />In the HQ56 heads, the 6948XL is the best deal. If you want to save some money and you aren't picky or in a hurry, the 6948XL will do the trick. The 6948XL is made in China and the fit and finish are not as good as the shavers made in Holland. However, I have had the newer Chinese shavers apart and the quality of the electronics is good. So if the extra cost is not a problem, by all means enjoy the PT730. And though it doesn't matter as much these days, the 730 is made in China as well. Looks like the 830 is the only model in this series still made in Holland.<br /><br />Just a quick note for anyone interested. It looks as though all the wet shavers will now only work cordless. Not a big problem, but for those of us who count on corded use, be aware. And watch for a better price near Christmas.
  1293. Quite, fast, and a smooth shave. This product is much better than the Panasonic it replaced. I'm a Norelco man from now on!
  1294. cannot beat this product for the price.
  1295. I love this thing; it's the best electric razor i've ever owned. It has vastly superior batteries compare with prior shavers I've used, too.
  1296. I bought this about a year ago. Works good. I like that you can use while it's plugged in or not. Only thing I dislike is the trimmer extends straight out instead of at an upper angle.

  1309. Shaving with this shaver is like running velvet across my face. Norelco has definitely mastered the mechanism of the rotating, floating blades.   1311. Service was excellent. Shaver worked great, and much quieter than old one. will buy another one when this one wears out.

  1313. good close shave, quiet, easy to clean. Charge lasts a long time
  1314. I have been through several electric razors, and I'm a fairly slow buyer, using my razors until they croak. My first electric was a rotary, and it didn't shave super close, but was comfortable, did the job, and had a decent lifespan.<br /><br />I bought my 2nd electric here, a Braun foil style that was pretty well reviewed. I liked it - the trimmer was quite effective, the shave was good, it held a charge well, and I could wash it easily with water. It was less comfortable than the rotary. It finally died.<br /><br />Now I have this one, and am very pleased! It's much quieter than my two predecessor models. The foil shaver must have prepped my face, because I could immediately get a very close shave, and with more comfort. In fact, it's so close that I have been doing every other day, and while I have some growth that way, I'm still socially acceptable. I agree with some folks that the trimmer could be better, but it's OK.<br /><br />And best of all, this one is even easier to thoroughly clean than the Braun. To do this, they recommend opening the rotary portion, washing, and then letting it dry open, which is fine by me - I get it almost showroom clean doing that, whereas the quick \\"un-opened\\" cleaning with the Braun allowed eventual accumulation of crud. I don't want any of that automated machine cleaning stuff like other models have, as it costs more, and I figure there's more stuff to break.<br /><br />All in all, it's so good that I almost like shaving now!?!!
  1315. I needed to replace my current electric (the blades were worn and it was going to be $20, again, original cost of old razor was ~$35). Went back to this rotary design, much closer shave, power lasts as advertised, replacement blades are a fair price. Very happy with the switch.

I am completely satisfied with this purchase and recommend to anyone wanting a fast close shave.

  1346. When I first held the Norelco PT730 the first thing I thought was 'cheap.' The whole thing is very thin plastic except for the blades and the motor sounds under-powered. However, after 3 months of use it has gotten worse not better. Apparently they also lie about having to replace the over-priced blades only every 12 months as well. I recently tried my dad's Braun razor and it did noticeably better around corners and edges without irritating my skin as much as this Norelco.<br /><br />PROs:<br />* Holds a charge for a while, approximately 1 - 2 weeks of daily use<br />* Quicker than manual razor for touch ups of flat surfaces of the face<br /><br />CONs:<br />* Not a close shave, does not get edges (manual razor required to get hair on and around chin as well as under jaw and around throat)<br />* Visibly irritates skin, feels awful<br />* Blades wear out 4x quicker than advertised<br />* Replacement blades are $25, half the price of the razor<br /><br />I'll be getting a Braun instead and would recommend the same.

  1377. I have a spine injury that I've lived with now for 11 months and one surgery, so far. Recently I concluded (reluctantly) that I could no longer shave safely with my trusty disposable blade razor, So I looked over the options for an electric, coming up with the Philips Norelco PT730 Powertouch as the best compromise between features and cost. (I also read attentively the reviews here.)<br /><br />First impressions can be misleading; Norelco, in it's little manual, warns new buyers to PLEASE use the razor for 3 weeks before drawing any conclusions. That was good advice. Initially I was ambivalent - and not only because I have a congenital dislike for electric razors. The PT730 seemed underpowered, even for my moderately light beard. But as time went by I developed a certain affection for the PT730 (the \\"Stockholm Syndrome\\"?).<br /><br />Now, after using the Norelco for almost a month, I believe it is very serviceable, comfortable and super-easy to clean. It rests in my hand so naturally the two seem custom-fitted to each other. I'm discovering little techniques, not initially obvious, that let me get a good shave in difficult-to-get-at places. Shaving is now a chore (a brief one), rather than something long and difficult.<br /><br />I haven't changed my mind on one thing: even a quite decent electric razor won't shave as close as the most humble 2-edge disposable blade. Not for my beard. But the former is more convenient to use and surely costs less in the long run -- or even the mid-term. So when closeness counts most, I know what to do. But for others with different priorities, and for blade-users like me when ill fate intervenes, it's nice to have a solid, comfortable performer like the Norelco PT730 available.

  1386. This razor gives a very close shave, but it has a few faults that kind of annoy me that I'm unable to look past and ignore. The three heads are guards for the blades underneath them. You run it across your face and the hair gradually find its way inside the guards and gets cut by the blades underneath. With this design you should not be getting cut while shaving. It will give you a nice close shave, but you have to run the razor across your face so often in the same spots multiple times in order to achieve this. Because of this it can easily irritate your skin. Other than that there is also the occasional pinch feeling when a hair is pulled from the skin before it has a chance to be cut by the blades. I think if it had a more powerful/faster motor, it would greatly reduce this problem and increase shaving time.<br /><br />The documentation that came with the product said that you're supposed to give it a couple months for your skin to adjust to it, which is about how long I've had it, but so far there have been no improvements for me. The first few times you shave with this thing though you will have patches of hair left over because you may not be familiar with the technique needed to best shave your face with it. You will at least get better with that over time.
  1387. I bought this as a supplement for my Fusion blade razor, for times when I am in a hurry, or whatever. Also, the price of blades keeps rising. The instructions say that you must use it for at least 30 days to get your skin accustomed to it, after which you can return it (up to 60 days), if not satisfied. It seems fair enough, so I did that, and I'm now up to a month or so.<br /><br />I am reasonably satisfied, but there is no way that it shaves as close as a blade. I certainly notice this toward the end of the day (having shaved in the morning), but it's not as if there is visible stubble. I can feel it when rubbing my hand over face and neck.<br /><br />It is a bit cumbersome to hold, as compared with the Braun I used to use occasionally and certainly takes up a lot more space, e.g., when packing it for a trip.<br /><br />The trimmer seems to have no effect at all.<br /><br />I will probably keep it rather than avail myself of the 60-day return option.
  1388. I bought this for my dad, and he like it. The price was good as well. good looking. no problem so far
