  1392. I bought this shaver last year and it still works good.
  1393. I've had a number of razors over the years and this is the quietest. It's plastic-y so not sure how long it will last. The power cord is a cheap stiff straight cable compared with the coiled, rubbery ones they used to have. This is designed to be rinsed but I prefer to brush it out after each shave. But unlike older models, this has a deep, hard to reach compartment and it's more difficult to clean. Have to say it shaves close! So far it's satisfactory.
  1394. Bought this for my father. He is very picky about his razor and says this one is a good one. He's 97 so he's been through a few razors. Ha! Would buy again. He is having me buy a spare head...just in case.
  1395. This is just an average razor. I bought this one because the higher end razors they have out wont work while they are charging. This one allows you to shave while plugged in but it takes 8hrs to charge.
  1396. I thought this razor as described would function as well as my previous razor (Norelco Model # 7240 XL). The new razor is adequate, however it does not shave as closely as my Norelco 7240 XL did..for many years.
  1397. A good light weight shaver. Does a good job but takes a little more time than the more expensive Norelco shavers.
  1398. Razor is what I expected from Phillips, it gives a smooth shave and it about $10.00 cheaper than the discount stores here.
  1399. A three-year-old Remington, which never really did work well (even with brand-new blades), suddenly bit the dust on Friday. I received my Philips-Norelco PT730 yesterday, charged it up, and used it for the first time this morning. Immediately, I was struck by how good it felt. There was no hint of pulling, and not even slight harshness on my skin.<br /><br />When I was done shaving, I ran the palm of my hand over my face and neck. Even with four full days' growth, I was as smooth as fine china! Blade-smooth, even.<br /><br />I'm duly impressed. Supposedly, an electric will take a few weeks to work at its optimum level. If that's true, I look forward to what it's going to be like next month.
  1400. This was supposed to be a Christmas give, but my hubby seized the package as soon as it arrived and has been using it daily. He loves this razor!
  1401. This is clearly NOT my old Norelco razor. I went cheap this time figuring why spend $100 more on a razor that was probably not much better than this one. I certainly hope the Norelco's that cost $100 more than this are MUCH better than this razor.<br /><br />I bought this razor back in March 2012, so I have been using it for over 5 months now.<br /><br />When it was new with a new set of blades I was concerned about it. It shaved. And it shaved what felt like close. But it did not feel right. It did not feel like the blades were turning that strongly. It felt weak. I would shave at around 6:30 AM each morning. It felt good. By the end of the day though, my beard was very rough. So it would get me through the day ok but at night, the family did not like a kiss from their dad or husband due to the roughness.<br /><br />I used to have the older 8200 series I think it was (maybe 8500) and that was a very different shave. It stayed much closer ALL day and into the night. Some days I would forget to shave the next day because it did not feel like it needed it. Of course, by 11:00 I would regret that but the point was that it was CLOSE. Much closer than this new razor.<br /><br />On top of that, the last month or so the shave has been getting rougher. The skin hurting after the shave. I figured the blades were getting dull but how could that be? It had only been 4 months then and the manual said to replace the blades after 1 year. Finally, after several more weeks of it getting rougher I bought a new set of blades. Ah! All better now. Nice and clean shave again and no burning sensation on the skin. So - don't expect to have these blades last a year.<br /><br />My beard is not thick or tough. So I definitely think my experience is about the best someone could expect. I know plenty of men who have thicker beard and I would think they would really hate this blade.<br /><br />Next time I need a new razor I will try Norelco one more time, and the more expensiveversions, in hopes that they did not throw quality out completely, just on their cheap line. They used to be the best. It would be a shame if they are just like all the rest now - crappy shaves that cost a lot.

  1421. My 5 year old Remington rotary (with 5 year old heads and blades)gives a much nicer, closer shave in about half the time as the PT730. Today I got the old Remington out and did half my face with the new one, half with the old one, and there was no comparison - will be using the old Remington until the battery finally dies.   1422. Met all expectations.
  1423. I finally had to retire my old model Norelco that I have used for several years. The second replacement rechargeable battery only lasted 6 months before self-destructing and, apparently frying the circuit board in the process. When I put in my 3rd replacement battery, it could not revive the old &#34;soldier&#34;. So I investigated and compared the currently available Norelco's. This seemed to fit my needs without getting into nuances of performance for which I have no need nor desire. I have a beard, and just try to keep it managed and my face reasonably smooth.<br />I have used various iterations of Norelco razor for 40 years. Even though this razor should have been somewhat of an upgrade from my previous model, in terms of features, this is the first time in memory that I experienced my new Norelco razor as a &#34;cheaper&#34; product than my old one. It's not just that it has a lighter &#34;heft&#34; from the old one, I realize that may be a function of the newer electronics. My experience is that the motor and rotors turn more slowly. The off/on switch doesn't &#34;feel&#34; as solid (granted it does have a cover to protect it from water). The trimmer, which I use every time I shave, does not have the solid mechanism to engage it that my old one had. The new one depends on freeing it up to allow a spring to pop it out. It is not as easy nor as convenient to engage. With my old one, I could just flip the razor in my hand; my thumb would just naturally come to rest on the mechanism, which I could engage by just pushing forward by straightening out my thumb. With this new one, after flipping the razor over, I have to work my way up towards the head, find the latch mechanism with my thumb, then pull it down. by flexing my thumb, to free the trimmer to pop out.<br />These seem like minor details, but they add up to just an &#34;Okay&#34; experience, after my old one. I also subjectively just don't trust that it will last as long as my old one. However, I like the Norelco shaving experience. I will keep it. I am not sure if I will try to keep it going when the battery fails by replacing the battery or look for something different. I don't know. This one may &#34;grow&#34; on me.

I charge the battery after four days use and it seems to have full power for my four shaves I clean it out frequently with the little brush it came with and thats all it needs. This is a simple unit with out the unecessary bells and whistles but still has the better quality lift and cut heads on the more expensive models. The pros are it's light can charge fairly quick, has pop up trimmer, and float-able heads that contour to your face (they aren't as good as I thought but that could be because I'm very skinny and have lot of bones that protrude more then the average guy). The cons are very simple motor is weak and the quality of all products these days is just lower than even 10 years ago. I also found a very interesting thing that it just doesn't do a good job by the neck area I read some other reviews who had the same issue. It also requires you to go over the same area a couple of times and then I noticed it got a little better after around 4 shaves I guess the heads needed some breaking in. Overall if you want a shaver that's not going to break the bank and gets the job done to anywhere between 95%-99% this would be a fair choice.<br />(I've been using it for a month now I'll update if things change)

  1459. This is my first ever electric shaver, and I am quite pleased with my purchase. I got tired of getting super irritated skin and cuts when shaving with a regular razor, and replacing the blades was super expensive. So I bought this one, and while it doesn't get as close as a regular razor, it still gets quite close in addition to being fast and easy to use. And I can still use my regular razor to get the hard-to-reach spots.<br /><br />It says in the manual that your skin may get irritated when you first start using it, and that was a bit true. But if you continue to use it your skin will grow accustomed to it, and it will be very pleasant to use.<br /><br />I don't know about the charge time since I unplug it, use it, and plug it back in again. But I haven't had any issues with the battery dying. In addition I've only had it for a few months, so I haven't had to deal with replacing the blade.<br /><br />Cleaning is very easy. Just pop open the top, rinse it out, dry off the outside, and leave it open to air dry. It's not meant to be used on a wet face though.<br /><br />All in all, this razor has made me fall in love with electric shavers. I highly recommend it.

  1472. For years I had considered changing from razor & lather to electric shaving but hesitated after reading harsh reviews of leading electric shavers. But the Philips Norelco PT730 lives up to the very positive reviews it has been getting, and I am glad I took the plunge. Its first test was a three-day growth of tough stubble that it handled well. I recommend reading the owner's manual and especially attending to the sound advice to use only the electric shaver (no lather shaving) for the first 21 days on a clean, dry beard--no magic lotions or potions needed. As best I can tell from my research, the newer cutting heads that come as original equipment on the PT730 provide some of the shaving success. I was also surprised and pleased by the very effective pop-up trimmer once I mastered its use. So far I have not run out of battery during a shave as I usually recharge after two thorough shaves. The PT730 is miles ahead of the foil shaver I tried years ago. So far, I find it well worth its modest purchase price.

  1570. I had been set against electric razors for a while; I had a Braun long ago, and it never did a good job. I am still in the adjustment phase, where my face is adapting to the change in techniques, but I can see a small improvement almost weekly now. Its still far from the smoothness I could get with a Mach3 Turbo shaving against the grain, but it takes 3 minutes to shave each morning, rather than 10, and the texture it leaves behind isn't objectionable, even to my picky spouse.<br /><br />Eventually I'd like to upgrade to a wet/dry model, but for now, this is a small investment I don't regret making.

  1577. This razor is awesome! I received it on 1/3/13, promptly charged it and started using it the next day. The motor is quiet (at least compared to the Remington I previously had) and runs smoothly. The instructions say to use it at least 3 weeks to allow your face to get used to it, but I got a close shave from the start. The rechargeable battery is supposed to last for 40 minutes or so. I was expecting to have to recharge at the end of week 2 or during week 3 of use, but the indicator light never came on. Weeks 4, 5, 6 and 7 all passed, allowing me to shave every morning (I never missed a day) without the battery dying. Here I am in week 8 and the orange recharge light finally came on this morning. That is amazing! I've had several electric razors over the years, and none of them held a charge this long. I am truly impressed. I have no complaints at all!
  1578. I've had this shaver for only a few weeks, but it does a better job than any previous shaver I've used over the past 60 years. It requires minimum passes over the same area, is very quiet, has a standard trimmer, is comfortable to hold, and is easy to rinse out after each use. I had worried about skin irritation, but this shaver has been gentle on my skin.   1605. I was a little hesitant to purchase this product. While the majority of the reviews were good, there were several that complained of being too weak, or not providing for a close enough shave. My experience has been quite different.<br /><br />I've been using the same Norelco 5801XL for probably about 20 years now! I was still not ready to replace this thing since it has been working so good, but when I found out recently that the replacement heads were very hard to find and about 1/2 the cost of a new razor, I gave in and decided to buy a new one. This was the one I settled on.<br /><br />I've been using it every day for two weeks now on a single charge, with no notable decrease in speed. While it may give the illusion of having less power than the old 5801XL I've been using, probably because it is so much quieter, it gives me an even closer shave than the 5801XL in about the same amount of time. There is also a notable difference in how much better it handles the thicker/more stubborn hairs. I'm guessing that has a lot to do with the new head design allowing for different size hairs. I would constantly have to use the hair trimmer accessory with the 5801XL to get those hairs, but have so for not had to do it with this one.<br /><br />I also like how much easier it is to clean the head and also the ability to wash it under running water.<br /><br />Overall, as compared to the 5801XL that I have been so happy with over the years, I think this one is definitely a step up.<br /><br />Update 2/17/2013: With daily use from a full charge, the battery lasted a good two months! Very impressive. It's amazing how much better these Lithium Ion batteries are compared to the old ones.

By the time I would give up on the Norelco, my neck was irritated and dotted with small nicks. Then I would have to follow up with a razor- which kinda defeats the whole purpose of using an electric shaver. Norelco recommends an \\"adjustment period\\" of 3 weeks to get used to this sort of misery, but it's been 2 weeks and I'm done with this thing. Don't buy it!
  1614. I use this razor everyday, very fashionable, water proof, I charge it once a week and lasts for the whole week. It does so much that I can't really think of any reason to buy any of the higher up models...
  1615. I bought for my 17 son and he loves ! Charges well and no more worries about him cutting himself as he doesnt have a full beard but def needs a shave everyday ! Easy and simple...great quality !

  1619. I have been using Norelco shavers for most of my life. When my last one died, I was dismayed with the poor reviews the &#34;new&#34; Senso Touch line was receiving on Amazon and other sources. As a result, I opted for the Powertouch that closely resembled my previous purchase.<br /><br />Boy, was I wrong! This shaver is nothing like my last shaver. The rechargeable batteries are cheap, low capacity versions. The motor is light weight, but not because it's efficient. It's a cheesy, low speed and low torque Asian boat (Chinese junk), that can barely make it through my relatively mild beard. And forget about getting a close shave... if you like the night life, you're going to have to shave twice a day with this baby.<br /><br />Unless you're someone who barely needs to shave and is looking for a cheap shaver, don't waste your money.

I have always appreciated a shaver that can be washed under the faucet and this work well. Others that also have revolving blades built up debris that never seems to wash away without a stiff brushing, not so with this shaver.<br /><br />UPDATE: 7/12/14<br />I wrote the above review prior to receiving new blades for my old shaver. Now I thoroughly regret the lavish praise. Not because of the shave I still get but because of the Manufacturer. I bought here on Amazon HQ8 blades as indicated on the the shaver. However, the branded Norelco HQ8 did not fit the shaver, even after an hour of twisting and turning the blade units each and every way. The solution was to remove the actual blade from its head cover and insert into the original covers. What they sold me was not what was pictured on Amazon and not HQ8 replacement units that would fit the shaver. I now regret having given five stars. So, now I reduce it to two stars because you cannot replace the blades without a hassle.

I think the blade design results in too little surface area to quickly cut through thick head (and face) hair. I'm returning this razor and going back to Remington. They seem to have more blade surface and while they're louder, they cut through more hair more quickly and closely. Especially on my head.

  1674. I have two current electric razors, both Panasonics. The ES8017 is a lower end entry unit (3 years) and the ES8249 (1.5 years) which is a higher end razor (with charging/cleaning/drying station). I have a normal beard and generally perfer an actual blade razor, but appreciate the speed and abiltity to shave without lotion an electric offers. The Panasonics do a good job on my cheeks and jaw line but struggle a bit on the neck hair, which tends to grow in different directions. I was interested to see if this Norelco would far better.<br /><br />Out of the box, I noticed how light the Noreclo was. Despite the lack of heft, the build seemed good with the plastic having no stress marks or burring. It also fit together well with no noticeble defects. I charged it over night and the next morning gave it a go.<br /><br />It is quiet in comparison to the panasonics, very quiet. I was a bit worried intially that it was getting not getting full power having been used to the power tool like sound and vibration from the pany's. However once on my face it cut cleanly and quickly. It did a great job on my face and jawline. It also outperformed the panasonics on the lower neck, actually being able to cut all the hair and not leaving a scattered few. Have used it for most of the week now with no complaints and haven't needed to recharge it. The cut is very close, I would say not quite a blade but a bit closer then the panasonics. It also does better with very short stubble then the panasonics. If I blade shave the day prior, they often have trouble picking up the stubble the next day, no such issue with the norelco. It does also have the usual flip up sideburn cutter on the back of the unit.<br /><br />Other then the razor and charging plug it comes only with a cleaning brush and snap on blade cover. I would have liked to have seen it ship with a soft case of some sort for travel. I will update in a few months to see if the unit continues to perform as the blades wear. If I have any concern it is as they dull it may lose performance but don't want to prejudge. New and out of the box though it does an excellent job. I liked both my Panasonics and will still use them (one for travel and one at work) but the Noreclo suprisingly is going to replace the ES8249 at home.

  1682. Previously used the Norelco Reflex Plus 6853XL cordless since 2005. This new PT730 is WAY better! Quieter and closer shave, comfortable, cleans easily with water, and charge should last about 10 days. Shaves a 3 day growth super easy where the other model struggled. Very happy with this new Norelco. FYI--previous model made in China--new model made in Netherlands.<br /><br />UPDATE Cinco de Mayo, 2014: razor still performing flawlessly with original cutters [neglected to mention in original review that I have a typical Italian bred beard]. I have not had to do any thorough cleanings with taking cutters out and brushing. No need. Only rinsing under the faucet for nearly a year cleans it all. So quick and easy. This is so much better than previous Norelco cutters accumulating stubble constantly and needing 30 minutes to take apart and brush. Honestly, I don't know how you could get a better razor or more comfortable results than a rotary Norelco. Even if you had to throw it away after 1 year it's still worth $50/yr. Thankfully, that's not the case as new cutters are $23 here at Amazon. Great razor!

  1690. Have had this for almost 2 years now, and replaced the blade one time already (they are available locally at most store chains). I have very fine facial hair (mostly). I find it works well on flat areas IE my cheeks and such. Where this really lacks is on the edge areas of my jaw and chin, it does not cut very closely, I have to pull and spread the skin around.<br /><br />I also have issues using this product on my neck. Even after using it for this long (no regular razors, electric only) my neck is still too sensitive for it. It nicks the HECK out of my neck if I make too many passes trying to get the stray hairs. It makes it worse if I pull down to flatten the skin of my neck. It looks like I was attacked by a vicious poodle or something. The abrasions scab up for days after. Knowing that, and only making 1 or 2 passes, it does just fine.<br /><br />I am very prone to severe break outs on my chin and neck from a regular razor. This electric very seriously minimizes that.<br /><br />Overall for my purposes, it works just fine. For me (others may have different results) I find that my face is never smooth, it always feels a little rough. I would think if someone had really dark hair they may have issues looking like they have a 5 o' clock shadow. My hair is blond and some red so it doesn't do that for me.<br /><br />The Battery is amazing, I rarely have to charge it.

  1727. I've been a longtime Norelco user so I was already used to the shave from this type razor, but this one really does a great job. The floating heads are extremely comfortable. Two Norelcos ago the razor came with a nice hard plastic case; one time ago the razor came with a cheap soft plastic case; this time the razor doesn't have any case at all--I guess they are cutting costs and not sacrificing the important part--a quality shave. I heartily recommend this razor

I did a lot of research for an electric shaver and had I have taken the quality of an razor more seriously, I might have been more willing to spend more on a razor.<br /><br />This product is good if the price is the maximum you are willing to spend on a razor but I now know that I should have spent twice as much so that I can get a reliable razor.

  1763. I have been using electric screen shavers for the past 30 years. They were all Remingtons except for the one I had for the last 10 years which was a Braun Flex Integral. They all gave a good shave.<br /><br />My Braun Flex Integral got old and didn't cut it anymore (pun intended). The motherboard had already been replaced once at a cost of $38. I decided to try a rotary electric razor because it can shave in all directions due to the way rotary's are built.<br /><br />When I received it, I immediate gave it a try using the battery power it had when it arrived. I was amazed at how close it got. My chin hairs were still showing stubble after used the old Braun, but the Norelco PT730 cut everything very close. No stubble anywhere on my face. As mentioned, my skin was already used to shaving with an electric shaver so my face had already adapted to using an electric.<br /><br />I chose this Norelco model because I wanted one that could shave with or without the power cord, in case the battery was dead. This removed any choice of the shavers that could be used in the shower (wet/dry types) because by definition a wet/dry electric shaver isn't made that can be used with the powercord because you would be electrocuted in the shower. Additionally, if I am already in the shower I can use a regular blade to shave, although I'm not a big fan of blade shavers because of I sometimes get razor burn,<br /><br />I also like that this model can be cleaned under running water, unlike the Norelco PT720 which needs to be cleaned with a brush. Rinsing with water does a better job of cleaning it than a brush does.<br /><br />This shaver also traps all the cut whiskers in the \\"reservoir\\" behind the cutters. Most of my foil shavers let many of the hairs fall onto my shirt, not the biggest problem in the world, but now my wife (who keeps her car interior super-clean) lets me use this shaver when I'm in her car.<br /><br />Remember that you don't need to use a lot of pressure against your face. That will only bend the screens and the cutters. A light approach is all you need.
  1764. I bought for my father's friend. he don't use yet. hope it will be good. I search the feedback in the internet,most people like this style.

  1767. This is my fourth Norelco shaver. The first two gave me satisfactory results. The third one, purchased two years ago was a disaster. It was the most expensive one yet, but performed poorly as a shaver. It needed to be charged frequently and in less than a year's time the head assembly fell apart while I was cleaning it. Reassembling it did no good. As soon as I turned it on, it fell apart again repeatedly.<br />I bought the PT 730 from Amazon after reading the reviews. It had the features I was looking for and it was very reasonably priced.<br />The features I wanted and found on this shaver: it can be used with or without the cord, it can give you a<br />'quick charge shave', it has a sideburn trimmer (an essential feature that not all shavers have).<br />And most importantly, it gives me a comfortable, non-irritating, close (for a machine) shave. And the relatively quiet motor is a bonus.<br />I have noticed some gripes about how shavers don't compare to blades. This is astounding! Why would anyone expect a machine to shave as closely as a blade? You're using a machine for its CONVENIENCE. It's quicker than shaving with a blade, there's no messing with shaving cream and there's no need for styptic pencils. The fact that they shave as closely as they do, is icing on the cake.

  1794. I was waffling between four and five stars, but settled on four.<br />Nice, long charge. Goes much longer between charges than my older model, even before it started not to hold as much charge.<br />It's funny - every time I get a new Norelco, it sounds different than the previous models.<br />Shaves nicely, trims nicely.<br />Only caveat: Don't judge it after the first charge. The first charge didn't last all that long and I thought I was going to be disappointed; however, the very next charge has lasted and lasted.<br />Only negative: It didn't come with any kind of stand, and the shape is slightly different from my last one, so the stand I'm keeping it in leaves me a bit unsure. Will it tip over? SO...I keep the travel cap on the blades in case it falls. Almost every time I go to remove the cap, the blades spring open because the release is right at the front of the blade unit. If it came with its own storage stand, it would be five-star rating.
  1795. This replaced an old Norelco electric razor with a trimmer that died after ten plus years. I was shocked at how light and cheap feeling this new razor was. However, when I shaved my neck and face, I was impressed at how good a job it did. Unfortunately, the trimming function was the main reason I purchased this razor and it is very poorly designed. Compared to my previous razor, which had a solid metal slide to open and close the trimmer, this trimmer is as cheap as they come. Further, the angle of the trimmer is almost 90 degrees to the razor vs 45 degrees from my older razor. At 90 degrees, the razor gets in the way so you cannot see very well to trim your beard and moustache. The off/on button is hard to find and push as is the trimmer button. Also the button does not close the trimmer as before. The trimmer function is hugely inferior and not recommended although the shave is good. For my purposes, I would not buy again.
  1796. This is my third Norelco electric razor, all of which have had long service lives. I like the PT730 the best so far because of the close shave it delivers at such a low cost.   1797. I purchased it at least a month or two ago. It works better if you shave without lotion on your body, when you legs are dry. However, it takes a few rounds to get almost all the hair off. However, for the price it's ok for now.
